sub_topics.short_description: Understanding languages used for common communication between speakers of different native languages.
example_tasks: Define lingua franca and identify English as the dominant global lingua franca due to British colonialism and American economic influence
Compare historical lingua francas (Latin in medieval Europe, Arabic in Islamic world, Swahili in East Africa) with modern ones
Analyze the spread of English and its impact on local languages and cultures

sub_topics.name: Language Diversity and Endangerment
sub_topics.short_description: Examining linguistic diversity and threats to minority languages.
example_tasks: Research that approximately 7,000 languages exist today but many are endangered with fewer than 1,000 speakers
Explain factors causing language extinction including globalization, urbanization, and dominance of major languages
Identify regions of high linguistic diversity such as Papua New Guinea (800+ languages) or Indonesia

sub_topics.name: Official Languages and Language Policy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding government designation of languages for official use.
example_tasks: Compare countries with one official language (France: French) versus multiple official languages (Switzerland: German, French, Italian, Romansh)
Explain how colonial history influences official languages in former colonies (English in India, French in West Africa, Spanish in Latin America)
Discuss controversies over language policy such as debates about official language status in multilingual nations

sub_topics.name: Dialects, Pidgins, and Creoles
sub_topics.short_description: Examining language variations and contact languages.
example_tasks: Define dialect as a regional variety of a language (British English vs. American English) that is mutually intelligible
Explain pidgin languages as simplified contact languages used for trade and communication between groups without common language
Describe how creoles develop when pidgins become native languages for new generations, gaining complexity (Haitian Creole, Jamaican Patois)

sub_topics.name: Religion and Belief Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the spatial distribution, diffusion, and landscape impacts of major world religions.

sub_topics.name: Universalizing Religions
sub_topics.short_description: Examining religions that actively seek converts worldwide.
example_tasks: Identify the three major universalizing religions: Christianity (2.4 billion), Islam (1.9 billion), and Buddhism (500 million)
Map the global distribution of Christianity, Islam, and Buddhism, identifying major concentration areas
Explain why universalizing religions spread more widely than ethnic religions through missionary activity and conversion

sub_topics.name: Ethnic Religions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding religions tied to specific ethnic groups or regions that don't actively seek converts.
example_tasks: Identify major ethnic religions including Hinduism (1.2 billion, primarily South Asia), Judaism (15 million), and various indigenous beliefs
Explain why ethnic religions remain concentrated in origin regions rather than spreading globally
Describe characteristics of ethnic religions including strong connection to place, ethnic identity, and ancestral traditions

sub_topics.name: Religious Diffusion Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how religions spread through relocation and expansion diffusion.
example_tasks: Compare Christianity's spread through relocation diffusion (missionaries traveling) and expansion diffusion (converting populations)
Trace Islam's diffusion from Arabian Peninsula through trade routes, conquest, and missionary activity
Explain how Buddhism diffused from India to East Asia and Southeast Asia along trade routes

sub_topics.name: Religious Landscapes and Architecture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how religious beliefs shape physical landscapes.
example_tasks: Identify characteristic religious structures: Christian churches with steeples and crosses, Islamic mosques with domes and minarets, Buddhist temples and pagodas, Hindu temples
Explain how religious buildings reflect theological concepts (Gothic cathedrals reaching toward heaven, Islamic geometric patterns avoiding human images)
Compare religious landscape features in different regions, such as church density in Christian areas versus mosque density in Muslim areas

sub_topics.name: Religious Conflict and Coexistence
sub_topics.short_description: Examining interfaith tensions and cooperation in pluralistic societies.
example_tasks: Research religious conflicts such as Hindu-Muslim tensions in South Asia, Christian-Muslim tensions in Nigeria, or Buddhist-Muslim tensions in Myanmar
Identify regions where multiple religions coexist peacefully such as Singapore or Lebanon (before civil war)
Explain how religious differences can combine with ethnic, economic, or political factors to intensify conflicts

sub_topics.name: Cultural Diffusion Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how cultural traits spread across space through various mechanisms.

sub_topics.name: Relocation Diffusion
sub_topics.short_description: Examining spread through physical movement of people.
example_tasks: Define relocation diffusion as spread through migration, where people move and bring their culture to new locations
Analyze examples such as Spanish language diffusing to Latin America through colonization or Hinduism to Trinidad through indentured labor migration
Compare relocation diffusion with expansion diffusion where ideas spread but people stay in place

sub_topics.name: Types of Expansion Diffusion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding hierarchical, contagious, and stimulus diffusion patterns.
example_tasks: Define hierarchical diffusion as spreading from larger/more influential places to smaller ones (fashion trends starting in major cities)
Explain contagious diffusion as spreading through direct contact like a disease (viral internet memes, musical crazes)
Describe stimulus diffusion where the underlying idea spreads but is modified (McDonald's adapting menus for local tastes)

sub_topics.name: Barriers to Cultural Diffusion
sub_topics.short_description: Examining physical, political, and cultural obstacles that slow or prevent spread.
example_tasks: Identify physical barriers like mountains, deserts, and oceans that historically limited cultural exchange
Explain how political barriers such as closed borders, trade restrictions, and censorship prevent cultural diffusion
Describe cultural barriers including language differences, religious prohibitions, and resistance to foreign influences

sub_topics.name: Time-Distance Decay and Diffusion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how distance and time affect the speed and pattern of cultural spread.
example_tasks: Explain time-distance decay principle: cultural traits spread less effectively over longer distances and take more time
Compare historical diffusion rates (Christianity taking centuries to spread to Europe) with modern rates (social media trends spreading globally in hours)
Analyze how transportation and communication technology has accelerated diffusion and reduced the effect of distance

sub_topics.name: Cultural Diversity and Identity
sub_topics.short_description: Examining cultural variation, multiculturalism, and forces of cultural convergence versus divergence.

sub_topics.name: Ethnicity and Race
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding cultural identity based on shared heritage versus socially constructed categories.
example_tasks: Define ethnicity as shared cultural characteristics (language, religion, customs, ancestry) that create group identity
Explain how race is a socially constructed category based on perceived physical differences, not biological reality
Compare ethnic diversity in countries like the United States (many ethnic groups) versus Japan (relatively homogeneous)

sub_topics.name: Multiculturalism and Cultural Pluralism
sub_topics.short_description: Examining societies with multiple coexisting cultural groups.
example_tasks: Define multiculturalism as the coexistence of different cultural groups maintaining their identities within a larger society
Compare multicultural policies in Canada (celebrating diversity) versus assimilation expectations in some European countries
Identify multicultural cities like Toronto, London, or Singapore where dozens of ethnic groups coexist

sub_topics.name: Acculturation and Assimilation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding processes by which minority groups adopt aspects of dominant culture.
example_tasks: Define acculturation as adopting elements of a new culture while maintaining original cultural identity
Contrast with assimilation where minority groups fully adopt dominant culture and lose original identity
Analyze immigrant experiences in the United States, where second and third generations often experience language shift and cultural change

sub_topics.name: Cultural Globalization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the worldwide spread of cultural traits and homogenization concerns.
example_tasks: Define cultural globalization as the increasing interconnection and homogenization of world cultures
Identify evidence of globalization such as worldwide recognition of American brands, English language dominance, and global entertainment
Debate whether globalization causes cultural convergence (similarity) or if local cultures maintain distinctiveness

sub_topics.name: Cultural Preservation and Revival
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding efforts to maintain and revitalize traditional cultures.
example_tasks: Research cultural preservation efforts such as language revitalization programs for indigenous languages
Explain UNESCO World Heritage Sites as recognition and protection of culturally significant places
Analyze tensions between modernization/globalization and cultural preservation in developing countries

name: Urban Geography
short_description: Investigation of urbanization processes, city structures, urban planning, and challenges facing cities globally. Students examine the growth, organization, and sustainability of urban areas.

sub_topics.name: Urbanization Process and Trends
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the historical and contemporary shift from rural to urban living.

sub_topics.name: Defining Urban Areas
sub_topics.short_description: Examining criteria used to classify settlements as urban versus rural.
example_tasks: Compare different definitions of urban areas: population thresholds (varying from 2,000 to 50,000 depending on country), population density, and economic activities
Explain the difference between city (legal/political boundary) and metropolitan area (functional urban region including suburbs)
Research how your country officially defines urban areas and applies this to your local region

sub_topics.name: Global Urbanization Trends
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the dramatic increase in urban population worldwide.
example_tasks: Interpret data showing that global urban population surpassed rural population around 2007, and is projected to reach 68% by 2050
Compare urbanization rates in developed countries (80%+ already urban) versus developing countries (rapid urbanization ongoing)
Map the most urbanized regions (North America, Europe, Latin America) versus least urbanized (sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia)

sub_topics.name: Causes of Urbanization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining rural-to-urban migration driven by push and pull factors.
example_tasks: Identify push factors driving rural-urban migration: agricultural mechanization, lack of rural opportunities, poverty, land scarcity
List pull factors attracting people to cities: employment opportunities, better services (education, healthcare), entertainment, infrastructure
Analyze how the Industrial Revolution triggered mass urbanization in 19th century Europe and North America

sub_topics.name: Megacities and Megalopolis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the emergence of extremely large urban agglomerations.
example_tasks: Define megacity as urban agglomeration with 10+ million people and identify examples: Tokyo (37 million), Delhi (32 million), Shanghai (28 million)
Explain megalopolis as continuous urban region formed by multiple cities growing together (Boston-Washington corridor, Tokyo-Osaka)
Compare the number of megacities in 1950 (2) versus 2020 (33) and project future growth

sub_topics.name: Urban Structure and Models
sub_topics.short_description: Examining theories and patterns of how cities are organized spatially.

sub_topics.name: Central Business District (CBD)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the commercial and financial core of cities.
example_tasks: Identify CBD characteristics: highest land values, concentration of offices and retail, vertical development (skyscrapers), low residential population, peak daytime activity
Explain why CBDs develop at the most accessible location, often where transportation routes converge
Compare traditional single-core CBD cities with polycentric cities that have multiple business centers

sub_topics.name: Concentric Zone Model (Burgess)
sub_topics.short_description: Examining urban growth in rings radiating from the CBD.
example_tasks: Draw the concentric zone model showing five zones: CBD, transition zone (warehouses, poor housing), working-class residential, middle-class residential, commuter zone
Explain how this model was based on Chicago in the 1920s and assumes transportation is equally easy in all directions
Identify limitations: assumes flat terrain, no geographic barriers, uniform transportation access

sub_topics.name: Sector Model (Hoyt)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how urban areas develop in wedge-shaped sectors along transportation routes.
example_tasks: Diagram the sector model showing how similar land uses extend outward from the CBD along transportation corridors
Explain why high-income residential areas often develop in sectors with amenities (waterfronts, hills, parks) while industry follows rail lines
Compare the sector model's recognition of transportation corridors with the concentric zone model's circular pattern

sub_topics.name: Multiple Nuclei Model (Harris-Ullman)
sub_topics.short_description: Examining cities with multiple centers of activity rather than a single CBD.
example_tasks: Describe how the multiple nuclei model shows specialized districts forming around separate nodes: CBD, port, university, industrial park, suburban mall
Explain why certain activities cluster together (retail districts) while others repel each other (heavy industry and high-income housing)
Identify modern examples like Los Angeles that fit the multiple nuclei pattern better than older models

sub_topics.name: Urban Realms and Edge Cities
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding contemporary metropolitan areas with suburban business centers.
example_tasks: Define edge cities as suburban nodes with 5+ million square feet of office space, 600,000+ square feet of retail, and more jobs than bedrooms
Explain how automobile dependence and highway systems enabled development of edge cities like Tyson's Corner (Virginia) or Irvine (California)
Compare traditional monocentric cities (single CBD dominant) with polycentric metropolitan areas

sub_topics.name: Urban Land Use Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how different activities occupy space in cities and factors influencing location decisions.

sub_topics.name: Bid-Rent Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how land values decrease with distance from CBD.
example_tasks: Explain bid-rent theory: businesses that benefit most from central location (retail, finance) can pay highest rent, while land-extensive uses (warehouses, housing) locate farther out
Graph bid-rent curves for commercial, residential, and agricultural land use showing how each peaks at different distances
Analyze how modern telecommunications and remote work may be changing traditional bid-rent patterns

sub_topics.name: Zoning and Land Use Regulations
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how governments control land use through zoning laws.
example_tasks: Define zoning as government designation of permitted land uses for different areas: residential, commercial, industrial, mixed-use
Explain purposes of zoning: separating incompatible uses, controlling density, preserving character, protecting property values
Debate advantages (ordered development, protection from nuisances) versus disadvantages (reduced flexibility, potential exclusion) of zoning

sub_topics.name: Gentrification
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the transformation of low-income neighborhoods through investment and middle-class influx.
example_tasks: Define gentrification as the renovation of deteriorated urban areas by middle-class residents, displacing lower-income residents
Identify indicators of gentrification: rising property values, new businesses (coffee shops, boutiques), demographic change, displacement
Debate positive effects (neighborhood improvement, tax revenue) versus negative effects (displacement, loss of affordable housing, cultural change)

sub_topics.name: Suburbanization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the growth of residential areas on city peripheries.
example_tasks: Trace suburbanization history in the United States: streetcar suburbs (1890s-1920s), automobile suburbs (1920s-1950s), mass suburbanization (post-WWII)
Identify factors driving suburbanization: desire for space and yards, automobile ownership, highway construction, white flight, affordable housing
Analyze consequences including urban sprawl, automobile dependence, infrastructure costs, and loss of farmland

sub_topics.name: Urban Sprawl
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding low-density, automobile-dependent development spreading outward from cities.
example_tasks: Define urban sprawl characteristics: low-density single-family homes, strip malls, separated land uses, automobile dependence, leapfrog development
Calculate how sprawling cities like Atlanta or Phoenix consume far more land per capita than compact cities like New York or San Francisco
Evaluate environmental and social costs of sprawl: habitat loss, air pollution, traffic congestion, social isolation, infrastructure expenses

sub_topics.name: Urban Challenges and Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing social, economic, and environmental issues facing cities globally.

sub_topics.name: Housing Affordability and Homelessness
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the lack of affordable housing in many urban areas.
example_tasks: Research housing affordability crisis in cities like San Francisco, New York, London, or Hong Kong where median home prices exceed 10x median income
Explain factors contributing to unaffordable housing: limited supply, geographic constraints, zoning restrictions, foreign investment, speculation
Identify strategies to address housing affordability: inclusionary zoning, public housing, rent control, density increases

sub_topics.name: Urban Poverty and Inequality
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding concentrated poverty and spatial inequality in cities.
example_tasks: Define urban poverty characteristics: inadequate housing, limited services, unemployment, crime, poor health outcomes
Compare poverty rates in inner cities versus suburbs, explaining historical patterns of concentrated urban poverty
Analyze how spatial segregation by income and race perpetuates inequality through unequal access to schools, jobs, and services

sub_topics.name: Transportation and Traffic Congestion
sub_topics.short_description: Examining urban mobility challenges and infrastructure strain.
example_tasks: Research cities with severe traffic congestion like Los Angeles, Jakarta, or Mumbai, analyzing average commute times and economic costs
Compare transportation solutions: expanding roads (often induces more traffic), public transit investment, congestion pricing, bike infrastructure
Evaluate the relationship between urban sprawl, automobile dependence, and traffic congestion

sub_topics.name: Urban Environmental Issues
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pollution, waste management, and ecological impacts of cities.
example_tasks: Identify urban environmental problems: air pollution, water pollution, urban heat islands, loss of green space, waste generation
Explain why cities have higher temperatures than surrounding areas (urban heat island effect) due to dark surfaces absorbing heat and lack of vegetation
Research air quality issues in heavily polluted cities like Delhi, Beijing, or Dhaka and health impacts on residents

sub_topics.name: Informal Settlements and Slums
sub_topics.short_description: Examining unplanned settlements lacking basic services in developing world cities.
example_tasks: Define informal settlements (slums, shantytowns, favelas) as unplanned housing lacking legal recognition and basic services
Research major informal settlements like Kibera (Nairobi), Dharavi (Mumbai), or favelas in Rio de Janeiro, analyzing populations and conditions
Explain why rapid urbanization in developing countries leads to informal settlement growth when formal housing can't keep pace with migration

sub_topics.name: Sustainable Urban Development
sub_topics.short_description: Examining strategies for creating environmentally, socially, and economically sustainable cities.

sub_topics.name: Smart Growth and New Urbanism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding principles for more sustainable, livable urban development.
example_tasks: List smart growth principles: mixed land uses, compact building design, walkable neighborhoods, transit-oriented development, preserved open space
Compare traditional suburban development (single-use zones, auto-dependent) with new urbanist design (mixed-use, pedestrian-friendly)
Research examples of new urbanist communities like Seaside, Florida or Stapleton, Denver

sub_topics.name: Green Infrastructure and Urban Ecology
sub_topics.short_description: Incorporating nature into cities through parks, green roofs, and urban forests.
example_tasks: Define green infrastructure as natural and semi-natural systems providing ecological services: stormwater management, air quality, cooling, habitat
Research examples like Singapore's 'city in a garden' approach, Portland's urban growth boundary preserving green space, or Copenhagen's green roofs
Explain benefits of urban trees: reducing heat island effect, filtering air pollutants, absorbing stormwater, providing habitat

sub_topics.name: Sustainable Urban Transportation
sub_topics.short_description: Developing transportation systems that reduce automobile dependence and emissions.
example_tasks: Compare transportation approaches: automobile-oriented (Los Angeles), transit-oriented (New York, Tokyo), bicycle-oriented (Copenhagen, Amsterdam)
Evaluate public transit systems including bus rapid transit (BRT), light rail, subways, and commuter rail
Research complete streets design that accommodates pedestrians, cyclists, transit, and automobiles rather than prioritizing cars

sub_topics.name: Energy-Efficient and Green Buildings
sub_topics.short_description: Designing buildings that minimize energy consumption and environmental impact.
example_tasks: Explain LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) certification for green buildings based on energy efficiency, water conservation, materials, indoor quality
Research features of green buildings: solar panels, green roofs, natural lighting, efficient HVAC systems, rainwater harvesting
Compare energy consumption in conventional buildings versus net-zero energy buildings that produce as much energy as they consume

sub_topics.name: Waste Reduction and Circular Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Moving from linear consumption (take-make-dispose) to circular systems that reuse resources.
example_tasks: Define circular economy as a system where resources are kept in use as long as possible through reuse, repair, remanufacturing, and recycling
Compare traditional waste management (landfills, incineration) with zero-waste approaches (composting, recycling, source reduction)
Research cities working toward zero waste goals like San Francisco, which diverts 80% of waste from landfills

name: Agricultural Geography
short_description: Understanding food production systems, agricultural regions, farming practices, and food security issues. Students examine how agriculture varies spatially and its environmental and economic impacts.

sub_topics.name: Origins and Development of Agriculture
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the transition from hunting-gathering to farming and domestication of plants and animals.

sub_topics.name: Neolithic Agricultural Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the independent development of agriculture in multiple hearths.
example_tasks: Identify major agricultural hearths where farming developed independently: Fertile Crescent (wheat, barley), China (rice, millet), Mesoamerica (corn, beans), Andes (potatoes), sub-Saharan Africa (sorghum, yams)
Explain how climate change at the end of the last ice age (warmer, wetter conditions) enabled agriculture around 10,000 years ago
Describe how agriculture allowed population growth, permanent settlements, and eventually the rise of civilizations

sub_topics.name: Plant and Animal Domestication
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding selective breeding that created modern crops and livestock.
example_tasks: Compare wild ancestors with domesticated varieties: wild teosinte versus modern corn, wild boar versus domestic pig, wild cattle (aurochs) versus modern breeds
Explain characteristics selected for domestication: larger seeds/fruit, loss of natural seed dispersal, docile behavior in animals, faster growth
Map the diffusion of domesticated species from hearths to other regions through trade and migration

sub_topics.name: First and Second Agricultural Revolutions
sub_topics.short_description: Examining major historical improvements in agricultural productivity.
example_tasks: Describe the First Agricultural Revolution (8000 BCE-1800s): transition to farming, simple tools, human and animal power, low yields
Explain the Second Agricultural Revolution (1700s-1900s): crop rotation, selective breeding, mechanization, chemical fertilizers, increased productivity
Compare how these revolutions affected population growth: agriculture enabled larger populations, improved agriculture enabled rapid growth

sub_topics.name: Types of Agricultural Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Classifying agriculture based on purpose (subsistence versus commercial) and intensity (inputs and yields).

sub_topics.name: Subsistence versus Commercial Agriculture
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing farming for self-consumption from farming for sale.
example_tasks: Define subsistence agriculture as growing food primarily for the farmer's family with little surplus for sale
Compare with commercial agriculture producing crops and livestock for sale in markets, often specialized in one or few products
Map global patterns showing subsistence agriculture dominant in developing countries while commercial agriculture dominates developed countries

sub_topics.name: Intensive versus Extensive Agriculture
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing high-input, small-area farming with low-input, large-area farming.
example_tasks: Define intensive agriculture as high inputs (labor, capital, fertilizer) per unit area producing high yields on small plots
Contrast with extensive agriculture using low inputs per unit area, requiring large land areas for viable production
Provide examples: intensive rice farming in Asia, extensive wheat farming in Great Plains, intensive greenhouse agriculture in Netherlands

sub_topics.name: Pastoral Nomadism
sub_topics.short_description: Examining mobile herding of livestock in marginal environments.
example_tasks: Describe pastoral nomadism characteristics: moving with herds to find pasture and water, raising sheep, goats, cattle, camels, living in arid/semi-arid regions
Identify regions where nomadic herding persists: Central Asian steppes, Middle Eastern deserts, East African savannas, Tibetan plateau
Explain how modern borders, agricultural expansion, and sedentary settlement pressures have reduced nomadic populations

sub_topics.name: Shifting Cultivation (Slash-and-Burn)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding subsistence farming that rotates through forest clearings.
example_tasks: Describe shifting cultivation process: clear forest, burn vegetation, plant crops, abandon after soil depletes (2-3 years), move to new plot
Explain why this system is sustainable with low population density and long fallow periods but degrades land when shortened rotation is practiced
Identify regions where shifting cultivation occurs: Amazon rainforest, Central Africa, Southeast Asia, though declining due to population pressure

sub_topics.name: Intensive Subsistence Agriculture: Wet Rice
sub_topics.short_description: Examining labor-intensive rice cultivation in paddies.
example_tasks: Describe wet rice (paddy) cultivation: flooded fields, transplanting seedlings, multiple crops per year in tropical areas, high yields, labor-intensive
Explain why wet rice cultivation dominates in densely populated regions of East, South, and Southeast Asia
Compare wet rice regions (abundant water, warm temperatures) with dry rice regions requiring different techniques

sub_topics.name: Plantation Agriculture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding large-scale commercial farming of export crops in tropical regions.
example_tasks: Define plantation agriculture: large estates, single crop (monoculture), tropical location, hired labor, production for export
Identify major plantation crops: coffee, tea, cocoa, bananas, sugarcane, rubber, palm oil
Trace colonial origins of plantations and ongoing concerns about labor conditions, environmental impacts, and economic dependency

sub_topics.name: Commercial Agriculture in Developed Countries
sub_topics.short_description: Examining mechanized, capital-intensive farming systems in North America, Europe, and other developed regions.

sub_topics.name: Mixed Crop and Livestock Farming
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding integrated systems growing crops and raising animals together.
example_tasks: Describe mixed farming where crops provide animal feed while livestock provides manure fertilizer, creating an integrated system
Identify regions where mixed farming dominates: American Midwest, Western Europe, parts of Australia
Explain advantages including risk diversification, soil fertility maintenance, and year-round farm income

sub_topics.name: Dairy Farming
sub_topics.short_description: Examining production of milk and dairy products near urban markets.
example_tasks: Explain why dairy farms traditionally located near cities due to milk's perishability (though refrigeration has expanded range)
Describe dairy farming characteristics: capital-intensive, requires regular labor, produces fluid milk, cheese, butter, yogurt
Compare dairy regions: Wisconsin, California, Netherlands, New Zealand, noting climate requirements (adequate moisture for pasture)

sub_topics.name: Commercial Grain Farming
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding extensive wheat and corn production for sale.
example_tasks: Identify major grain farming regions: Great Plains (wheat), Corn Belt (corn and soybeans), Canadian Prairies, Ukraine, Australia
Explain characteristics: extensive operations, high mechanization, relatively low labor, vulnerable to weather and price fluctuations
Compare spring wheat (planted spring, harvested fall) with winter wheat (planted fall, harvested summer) regions based on climate

sub_topics.name: Livestock Ranching
sub_topics.short_description: Examining extensive cattle and sheep raising on large properties.
example_tasks: Describe ranching characteristics: raising cattle or sheep on natural grasslands, extensive operations, arid/semi-arid locations
Identify major ranching regions: western United States, Argentina pampas, Brazilian cerrado, Australia outback
Explain how ranching differs from pastoral nomadism: sedentary, commercial orientation, primarily cattle

sub_topics.name: Mediterranean Agriculture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding specialized crops adapted to dry summer climates.
example_tasks: Identify Mediterranean agricultural regions: coastal California, Chile, Mediterranean Basin, South Africa, southern Australia
List characteristic crops suited to dry summers: grapes, olives, citrus, figs, various vegetables
Explain how irrigation enables high-value crop production in summer when natural rainfall is absent

sub_topics.name: Green Revolution and Modern Agriculture
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the application of science and technology to dramatically increase agricultural yields.

sub_topics.name: Green Revolution Technologies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding high-yield varieties, irrigation, fertilizers, and pesticides.
example_tasks: Identify Green Revolution components starting in 1960s: high-yield variety (HYV) seeds, irrigation, chemical fertilizers, pesticides, mechanization
Explain how HYV wheat and rice produced by scientists like Norman Borlaug doubled or tripled yields
Describe the Green Revolution's success in increasing food production, particularly in India and Mexico, averting predicted famines

sub_topics.name: Impacts and Limitations of Green Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Evaluating both benefits and problems created by agricultural intensification.
example_tasks: List positive impacts: increased yields, reduced hunger, population growth supported, some countries achieved food self-sufficiency
Identify negative impacts: environmental degradation, water depletion, loss of biodiversity, increased inequality (benefited wealthy farmers with capital)
Explain why Green Revolution was less successful in Africa due to different crops, climates, and lack of infrastructure

sub_topics.name: Biotechnology and GMOs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding genetic modification of crops and associated controversies.
example_tasks: Define genetically modified organisms (GMOs) as crops with DNA altered to express desired traits: pest resistance, herbicide tolerance, improved nutrition
Identify major GMO crops: corn, soybeans, cotton, canola, primarily in the United States, Brazil, Argentina
Debate GMO controversies: proponents cite increased yields and reduced pesticide use, opponents cite environmental and health concerns

sub_topics.name: Precision Agriculture
sub_topics.short_description: Applying technology for site-specific farm management.
example_tasks: Describe precision agriculture technologies: GPS, sensors, drones, satellite imagery, data analytics for optimizing inputs
Explain how precision agriculture allows variable rate application: applying different amounts of water, fertilizer, pesticides to different field zones
Evaluate benefits including increased efficiency, reduced input costs, environmental benefits from targeted application

sub_topics.name: Food Security and Agricultural Challenges
sub_topics.short_description: Examining global food supply issues, malnutrition, and obstacles to feeding the world's population.

sub_topics.name: Defining Food Security
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding access to sufficient, safe, nutritious food.
example_tasks: Define food security as existing when all people always have physical, social, and economic access to sufficient, safe, nutritious food
Distinguish between chronic food insecurity (long-term lack of access) and acute food insecurity (temporary crisis from conflict, disaster)
Research that approximately 800 million people worldwide experience chronic hunger despite sufficient global food production

sub_topics.name: Malnutrition: Undernutrition and Obesity
sub_topics.short_description: Examining both insufficient calories and excessive/unhealthy diets.
example_tasks: Define undernutrition as insufficient caloric intake or lack of essential nutrients, causing stunting, wasting, and micronutrient deficiencies
Contrast with overnutrition and obesity, increasingly affecting developing countries as they adopt Western diets
Explain the paradox of double burden: some countries face both undernutrition and obesity simultaneously in different populations

sub_topics.name: Environmental Sustainability of Agriculture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ecological impacts and need for sustainable practices.
example_tasks: Identify environmental problems from conventional agriculture: soil erosion, water depletion, pollution from fertilizers and pesticides, habitat loss, greenhouse gas emissions
Explain soil degradation through erosion, nutrient depletion, salinization, and desertification
Research sustainable agriculture practices: crop rotation, conservation tillage, integrated pest management, organic farming, agroforestry

sub_topics.name: Challenges of Feeding a Growing Population
sub_topics.short_description: Examining obstacles to meeting future food demand.
example_tasks: Calculate that world population growing from 8 billion (2025) to projected 10 billion (2050s) requires 50-70% more food production
Identify constraints on expanding production: limited arable land, water scarcity, climate change impacts, declining soil fertility
Evaluate solutions: improving yields, reducing food waste (1/3 lost or wasted), dietary changes (less meat), expanding aquaculture, urban agriculture

name: Economic Geography
short_description: Analysis of economic systems, resource distribution, industrial location, and global economic patterns. Students examine spatial aspects of production, distribution, and consumption.

sub_topics.name: Economic Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different approaches to organizing production and distribution of goods and services.

sub_topics.name: Traditional Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Examining economic systems based on customs, subsistence, and barter.
example_tasks: Define traditional economy as based on customs, traditions, subsistence activities, and barter rather than monetary exchange
Identify remaining traditional economies in remote indigenous communities and note their declining prevalence
Describe characteristics: little specialization, family/community-based production, sustainable resource use, economic stability but limited growth

sub_topics.name: Command (Planned) Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding government-controlled production and distribution decisions.
example_tasks: Define command economy as government making production decisions, owning means of production, and setting prices centrally
Identify historical and current examples: Soviet Union (historical), China pre-1980s (historical), North Korea, Cuba
Evaluate advantages (equality goals, full employment) and disadvantages (inefficiency, shortages, lack of innovation, low quality)

sub_topics.name: Market (Capitalist) Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Examining private ownership with production driven by supply and demand.
example_tasks: Define market economy as based on private ownership, profit motive, competition, and prices determined by supply and demand
Explain Adam Smith's concept of the 'invisible hand' where individual self-interest leads to efficient resource allocation
Identify examples of market-oriented economies: United States, Singapore, Hong Kong, though pure market economies don't exist

sub_topics.name: Mixed Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding combined market and government elements in most modern economies.
example_tasks: Define mixed economy as combining private enterprise with government regulation and provision of public goods
Explain that most countries are mixed economies with varying degrees of government involvement
Compare different mixed economy models: Nordic model (extensive welfare state), US model (more market-oriented), Chinese model (state capitalism)

sub_topics.name: Economic Sectors and Employment Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Classifying economic activities into primary, secondary, tertiary, and quaternary sectors.

sub_topics.name: Primary Sector Activities
sub_topics.short_description: Examining extraction and harvesting of natural resources.
example_tasks: Define primary sector as activities extracting resources from Earth: agriculture, fishing, forestry, mining, drilling
Explain how primary sector dominates employment in developing countries but represents small percentage in developed countries
Compare primary sector employment: sub-Saharan Africa (60%+), China (25%), United States (2%)

sub_topics.name: Secondary Sector Activities
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding manufacturing and processing of raw materials into finished goods.
example_tasks: Define secondary sector as transforming raw materials into manufactured products: factories, construction, food processing, textile production
Describe how industrialization historically shifted employment from primary to secondary sector
Identify countries with high secondary sector employment: China (29%), Germany (25%), South Korea (25%)

sub_topics.name: Tertiary Sector Activities
sub_topics.short_description: Examining provision of services rather than goods.
example_tasks: Define tertiary sector as service provision: retail, transportation, healthcare, education, hospitality, banking, entertainment
Explain how economic development leads to tertiary sector dominance: US (80%), UK (80%), France (76%) of employment
Describe why service sector has grown: increased income allows more spending on services, technology reduces need for manufacturing workers

sub_topics.name: Quaternary and Quinary Sectors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding information/knowledge work and high-level decision-making services.
example_tasks: Define quaternary sector as information and knowledge-based services: IT, research, education, consulting, financial services
Define quinary sector as highest-level decision-making: top executives, government officials, scientific research, high-level healthcare
Explain how these sectors represent increasing specialization and are concentrated in developed countries

sub_topics.name: Sectoral Shift and Development
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how employment shifts between sectors as countries develop.
example_tasks: Describe typical development pattern: primary → secondary → tertiary sector dominance
Explain why developing countries often have primary sector dominance while developed countries have tertiary/quaternary dominance
Analyze how some developing countries skip industrialization, moving from primary directly to services (India's IT sector)

sub_topics.name: Natural Resources and Distribution
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the spatial distribution of resources and their economic importance.

sub_topics.name: Renewable versus Nonrenewable Resources
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing resources that regenerate from those with finite supplies.
example_tasks: Define renewable resources as regenerating naturally: solar, wind, hydropower, biomass, geothermal, forests (if managed sustainably)
Contrast with nonrenewable resources formed over millions of years: fossil fuels (coal, oil, natural gas), most minerals
Explain the concept of sustainable yield: harvesting renewable resources no faster than regeneration rate

sub_topics.name: Fossil Fuel Resources
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding distribution and geopolitics of oil, natural gas, and coal.
example_tasks: Map major oil reserves showing concentration in Middle East (Saudi Arabia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, UAE), Venezuela, Russia, United States
Identify major natural gas producers: United States, Russia, Iran, Qatar, with growing importance of shale gas
Explain how uneven distribution of fossil fuels creates economic power for resource-rich countries and dependency for importers

sub_topics.name: Mineral Resources
sub_topics.short_description: Examining distribution of metallic and non-metallic minerals.
example_tasks: Identify major producers of key minerals: China (rare earth elements), Chile (copper), Australia (iron ore, lithium), DRC (cobalt)
Explain why mineral resources are unevenly distributed based on geological processes over millions of years
Discuss how demand for battery minerals (lithium, cobalt, nickel) is increasing with electric vehicle production

sub_topics.name: Resource Curse Paradox
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why resource-rich countries sometimes have poor development outcomes.
example_tasks: Define resource curse (Dutch disease) as paradox where countries with abundant natural resources often have worse economic and political outcomes
Explain mechanisms: currency appreciation hurting other exports, government corruption, neglect of other sectors, economic volatility
Compare resource-rich countries with good governance (Norway, Botswana) versus those with poor outcomes (Venezuela, Nigeria)

sub_topics.name: Industrial Location Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding factors influencing where industries locate their operations.

sub_topics.name: Weber's Least Cost Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Examining location decisions based on minimizing transportation and labor costs.
example_tasks: Explain Weber's theory: industries locate to minimize total costs from transporting raw materials and finished products plus labor costs
Define break-of-bulk points where goods are transferred between transportation modes (ports, rail terminals) as attractive industrial sites
Apply Weber's model to explain why heavy industries (steel mills) historically located near raw materials or markets depending on weight gain/loss in production

sub_topics.name: Situation and Site Factors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding relative location versus physical characteristics in industrial location.
example_tasks: Define situation factors as relative location considering transportation costs, market access, and proximity to inputs
Define site factors as physical characteristics: land, labor, capital availability, government policies, infrastructure
Provide examples: computer manufacturers locate near airports (situation) and skilled labor (site), bulk reduction industries near raw materials

sub_topics.name: Agglomeration Economies
sub_topics.short_description: Examining benefits of clustering similar industries in the same location.
example_tasks: Define agglomeration economies as cost savings from locating near related businesses: shared suppliers, skilled labor pool, knowledge spillover
Identify examples of industrial clusters: Silicon Valley (technology), Hollywood (entertainment), Detroit (historic auto manufacturing)
Explain how initial advantage leads to cumulative causation where success attracts more firms, reinforcing the cluster

sub_topics.name: Bulk-Gaining and Bulk-Reducing Industries
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how weight changes during production affect location decisions.
example_tasks: Define bulk-reducing industries as losing weight during production (copper smelting, paper mills), preferring locations near raw materials to reduce transport costs
Define bulk-gaining industries as adding weight or volume (bottling plants, furniture), preferring locations near markets
Provide examples: lumber mills near forests (bulk-reducing), soft drink bottling near consumers (bulk-gaining)

sub_topics.name: Measuring Economic Development
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding indicators used to measure and compare levels of development between countries.

sub_topics.name: GDP and GDP per Capita
sub_topics.short_description: Examining total economic output and average income measures.
example_tasks: Define GDP (Gross Domestic Product) as total value of goods and services produced within a country in a year
Calculate GDP per capita (GDP ÷ population) as better indicator of living standards than total GDP
Compare countries: US GDP per capita ~$75,000, China ~$12,000, India ~$2,400, recognizing limitations (doesn't measure inequality, informal economy, quality of life)

sub_topics.name: Human Development Index (HDI)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding composite measure including income, education, and health.
example_tasks: Explain HDI components: life expectancy (health), education (years of schooling), and GNI per capita (income)
Interpret HDI scale from 0 to 1: Very High (0.8+), High (0.7-0.799), Medium (0.55-0.699), Low (below 0.55)
Compare HDI rankings showing that income alone doesn't determine development: some countries with similar GDP have very different HDI due to health/education differences

sub_topics.name: Gini Coefficient and Inequality
sub_topics.short_description: Measuring income or wealth distribution within countries.
example_tasks: Define Gini coefficient as measure of inequality from 0 (perfect equality) to 1 (perfect inequality)
Compare countries: Scandinavia (~0.25, low inequality), United States (~0.41, moderate-high), South Africa (~0.63, very high inequality)
Explain that economic growth doesn't automatically reduce inequality; distribution depends on policies and institutions

sub_topics.name: Gender Inequality Index
sub_topics.short_description: Examining disparities between men and women in development outcomes.
example_tasks: Identify GII components: reproductive health, empowerment (education, parliamentary representation), labor force participation
Compare countries with low gender inequality (Nordic countries) versus high (sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia)
Explain how reducing gender inequality improves overall development by utilizing full potential of population

name: Political Geography
short_description: Study of political boundaries, geopolitics, territorial organization, and spatial aspects of political processes. Students examine how political power is organized and contested across space.

sub_topics.name: States, Sovereignty, and Territory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the modern state system and territorial control.

sub_topics.name: Defining the State
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the essential characteristics that define independent countries.
example_tasks: Identify the four essential elements of statehood: defined territory, permanent population, government, and sovereignty (recognition by other states)
Compare states (countries like France or Japan) with nations (cultural groups like Kurds or Basques who may lack a state)
Explain why entities like Taiwan or Palestine face disputed sovereignty despite having territory, population, and government

sub_topics.name: Sovereignty and Self-Determination
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding supreme authority within territory and peoples' right to choose their political status.
example_tasks: Define sovereignty as supreme and independent political authority over a territory, free from external control
Explain self-determination as the principle that peoples have the right to choose their own political status
Analyze conflicts between state sovereignty (territorial integrity) and self-determination (independence movements) in cases like Catalonia, Scotland, or Quebec

sub_topics.name: Nation-State Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the ideal of cultural and political boundaries coinciding.
example_tasks: Define nation-state as ideal where a nation (people with shared culture/identity) has its own state (political entity)
Identify examples approaching nation-state ideal: Japan, Iceland, Poland (relatively homogeneous populations)
Explain why most countries are actually multi-nation states with diverse populations (India, United States, Russia)

sub_topics.name: Stateless Nations and Multinational States
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding nations without states and states containing multiple nations.
example_tasks: Identify stateless nations: Kurds (distributed across Turkey, Iraq, Iran, Syria), Palestinians, Basques, Tibetans
Compare with multinational states containing many nations: India (hundreds of ethnic groups), Nigeria, Indonesia
Analyze challenges both create: stateless nations seek autonomy/independence, multinational states manage diversity and potential separatism

sub_topics.name: Political Boundaries and Borders
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how territories are divided, types of boundaries, and border disputes.

sub_topics.name: Types of Boundaries by Physical Feature
sub_topics.short_description: Classifying boundaries based on natural or geometric characteristics.
example_tasks: Define geometric boundaries as straight lines following latitude/longitude (US-Canada 49th parallel, many African borders)
Identify physical boundaries following natural features: rivers (Rio Grande), mountains (Pyrenees between France-Spain), lakes (Great Lakes)
Explain subsequent boundaries drawn after settlement (most European borders) versus antecedent boundaries drawn before settlement (many colonial borders in Africa)

sub_topics.name: Boundary Evolution and Classification
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how boundaries develop relative to cultural landscapes.
example_tasks: Define antecedent boundaries established before significant settlement (US-Canada border through empty land)
Compare subsequent boundaries drawn after settlement following cultural divisions (India-Pakistan partition)
Explain superimposed boundaries imposed by external powers ignoring cultural patterns (African borders from Berlin Conference 1884-85)

sub_topics.name: Boundary and Territorial Disputes
sub_topics.short_description: Examining conflicts over borders and territorial claims.
example_tasks: Identify types of boundary disputes: definitional (interpretation disagreement), locational (placement disagreement), operational (administration disagreement), allocational (resource distribution)
Research ongoing disputes: India-Pakistan (Kashmir), China-India (Aksai Chin/Arunachal Pradesh), Russia-Ukraine (Crimea), Israel-Palestine
Explain why territorial disputes often involve resources (oil, water, fishing rights) or strategic locations

sub_topics.name: Enclaves and Exclaves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding territories separated or surrounded by other states.
example_tasks: Define enclave as territory completely surrounded by another country (Lesotho within South Africa, Vatican within Italy)
Define exclave as part of a country separated from the main territory by another country (Kaliningrad exclave of Russia)
Identify semi-enclaves like Alaska (US exclave accessible by sea without crossing Canada) or create maps showing these unusual territorial arrangements

sub_topics.name: Maritime Boundaries and EEZ
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding territorial waters and exclusive economic zones in oceans.
example_tasks: Define territorial sea as 12 nautical miles from coast where states have full sovereignty
Explain Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) extending 200 nautical miles where states control resource extraction but allow navigation
Research disputes over maritime boundaries in South China Sea or Arctic Ocean where overlapping EEZ claims create conflicts

sub_topics.name: Forms of Government
sub_topics.short_description: Examining different systems of political organization and governance.

sub_topics.name: Democracy versus Authoritarianism
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing systems based on popular participation versus concentrated power.
example_tasks: Define democracy as government where power rests with citizens through voting and participation
Contrast with authoritarianism where power is concentrated in single leader or small group without genuine democratic processes
Use Freedom House rankings to classify countries as Free (democracies), Partly Free, or Not Free (authoritarian)

sub_topics.name: Unitary versus Federal Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding centralized versus divided power structures.
example_tasks: Define unitary systems with power concentrated in central government (France, Japan, most countries)
Compare with federal systems dividing power between national and regional governments (United States, Germany, Canada, India, Australia)
Explain advantages of federalism (local autonomy, accommodates diversity) and unitary systems (efficiency, uniformity)

sub_topics.name: Parliamentary versus Presidential Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing systems where executive comes from legislature versus separate election.
example_tasks: Define parliamentary system where executive (prime minister) is chosen by legislature and can be removed by vote of no confidence (UK, Germany, Japan)
Compare with presidential system where executive (president) is independently elected and has fixed term (United States, Brazil, Mexico)
Evaluate advantages: parliamentary systems promote cooperation between branches, presidential systems provide stability and separation of powers

sub_topics.name: Electoral Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how votes translate into political representation.
example_tasks: Define plurality/first-past-the-post systems where candidate with most votes wins (United States, UK), often creating two-party systems
Compare with proportional representation where parties receive seats matching vote percentage (Netherlands, Israel), enabling multi-party systems
Explain mixed systems combining both approaches (Germany, New Zealand) attempting to balance local representation with proportionality

sub_topics.name: Geopolitics and International Relations
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how geography influences political power and international relations.

sub_topics.name: Classical Geopolitical Theories
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding historical theories linking geography to power.
example_tasks: Explain Mackinder's Heartland Theory: control of Eastern Europe/Central Asia (the heartland) leads to world dominance
Describe Spykman's Rimland Theory emphasizing control of coastal areas surrounding Eurasia
Analyze how these theories influenced Cold War strategy and remain relevant to understanding US-China-Russia competition

sub_topics.name: Spheres of Influence
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding regions where major powers exert dominant influence.
example_tasks: Define sphere of influence as region where a major power has dominant political, economic, or military influence
Identify historical and current examples: US in Latin America (Monroe Doctrine), Russia in former Soviet republics, China in Southeast Asia
Explain how spheres of influence create tension when they overlap or when smaller states resist great power dominance

sub_topics.name: Buffer States and Strategic Locations
sub_topics.short_description: Examining countries serving as separation between rival powers.
example_tasks: Define buffer states as countries separating rival powers, reducing direct conflict (Afghanistan between British India and Russian Empire historically)
Identify strategic locations giving geographic advantage: Suez Canal (Egypt), Strait of Malacca (Singapore), Panama Canal
Explain how control of choke points (narrow passages controlling maritime traffic) provides geopolitical power

sub_topics.name: Supranational Organizations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding organizations where states yield some sovereignty to international bodies.
example_tasks: Define supranational organizations as entities with authority over member states in certain areas (European Union is primary example)
Compare with intergovernmental organizations where states cooperate but retain full sovereignty (United Nations, NATO, WTO)
Analyze how EU demonstrates supranationalism: common currency, free movement, European Parliament making laws superseding national laws

sub_topics.name: Balance of Power and Alliances
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how states form alliances to prevent dominance by any single power.
example_tasks: Explain balance of power theory: states form alliances to prevent any single state from dominating
Identify major alliance systems: NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization), SCO (Shanghai Cooperation Organization), ASEAN
Analyze how shifting alliances maintain balance: Cold War bipolar system (US-NATO vs. USSR-Warsaw Pact) versus emerging multipolar system

sub_topics.name: Devolution and Separatist Movements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding forces pulling states apart through regional autonomy demands and independence movements.

sub_topics.name: Devolution of Power
sub_topics.short_description: Examining transfer of authority from central to regional governments.
example_tasks: Define devolution as granting powers from central to regional/local governments while maintaining overall sovereignty
Identify examples: UK devolving powers to Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland; Spain's autonomous communities
Explain how devolution differs from federalism (devolution can be revoked by central government) and full independence

sub_topics.name: Causes of Devolutionary Pressures
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding factors driving demands for regional autonomy.
example_tasks: Identify physical factors: regions separated by mountains, deserts, or water may develop distinct identities (Sicily from mainland Italy)
Explain cultural factors: ethnic, linguistic, or religious differences from dominant group (Basques in Spain, Quebecois in Canada)
Describe economic factors: wealthy regions resenting supporting poorer areas (Catalonia in Spain) or poor regions feeling exploited

sub_topics.name: Separatist and Independence Movements
sub_topics.short_description: Examining movements seeking to create new independent states.
example_tasks: Research active separatist movements: Catalonia (Spain), Scotland (UK), Quebec (Canada), Kurdish regions (Turkey, Iraq, Iran, Syria)
Compare successful independence movements (South Sudan 2011, East Timor 2002, former Yugoslavia 1990s) with unsuccessful attempts
Analyze why central governments resist separatism: loss of territory/resources, fear of precedent encouraging other movements, national unity

sub_topics.name: Terrorism and Political Violence
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding use of violence for political goals.
example_tasks: Define terrorism as deliberate violence targeting civilians to achieve political goals through fear
Explain difference between state terrorism (government violence against citizens) and non-state terrorism (by groups against governments or populations)
Analyze how some separatist movements use terrorism (ETA in Basque region, IRA in Northern Ireland) while others pursue peaceful means (Scotland's independence referendum)

sub_topics.name: Colonialism and Decolonization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the historical impact of European colonialism and independence movements.

sub_topics.name: European Colonial Empires
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the expansion of European control over much of the world.
example_tasks: Identify major colonial powers and their empires: British (India, Africa, North America), French (Africa, Southeast Asia), Spanish (Latin America), Portuguese (Brazil, Africa)
Explain motivations for colonialism: resources extraction, markets for goods, strategic advantage, missionary activity, national prestige
Map the extent of colonialism at its peak (early 1900s) showing that Europeans controlled over 80% of world's land

sub_topics.name: Berlin Conference and Scramble for Africa
sub_topics.short_description: Examining European division of Africa with little regard for existing political or cultural boundaries.
example_tasks: Describe the Berlin Conference (1884-85) where European powers divided Africa without African representation
Explain how colonial borders were often geometric or followed physical features, ignoring ethnic/cultural distributions
Analyze lasting impacts: artificial borders creating multi-ethnic states or dividing single ethnic groups across multiple countries

sub_topics.name: Waves of Decolonization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the process of colonies gaining independence.
example_tasks: Identify three main waves: Latin America (1810s-1820s), Asia-Middle East (1940s-1950s), Africa (1950s-1970s)
Explain factors enabling decolonization: weakening of European powers after WWII, rise of nationalism, Cold War superpowers supporting decolonization, UN Charter supporting self-determination
Compare peaceful independence transitions (India, most African countries) with violent independence wars (Algeria, Vietnam, Angola)

sub_topics.name: Neocolonialism and Dependency
sub_topics.short_description: Examining continued economic and political influence despite formal independence.
example_tasks: Define neocolonialism as indirect control through economic dominance, debt, multinational corporations, and political pressure rather than direct political rule
Explain dependency theory: former colonies remain economically dependent on former colonizers through trade patterns, investment, and technology
Identify examples: French influence in West Africa (CFA franc currency), economic ties between Britain and Commonwealth, China's growing influence in Africa

name: Cartography and Geographic Technologies
short_description: Development of map-reading skills and introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS), GPS, and remote sensing. Students learn to create, analyze, and interpret spatial data.

sub_topics.name: Advanced Map Reading and Interpretation
sub_topics.short_description: Developing sophisticated skills in extracting information from various map types.

sub_topics.name: Topographic Maps
sub_topics.short_description: Reading contour lines to understand terrain and elevation.
example_tasks: Interpret contour lines to determine elevation, identify hills versus valleys, and calculate slope steepness (closely spaced contours = steep)
Use contour intervals to determine the elevation change between adjacent lines and calculate total elevation gain along a route
Identify landforms on topographic maps: ridges, valleys, saddles, depressions, and distinguish gentle slopes from cliffs

sub_topics.name: Climate Maps and Graphs
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting climate data visualizations including climatographs.
example_tasks: Read climatographs (climate graphs) showing monthly temperature and precipitation patterns and classify climate types
Compare multiple climatographs to identify patterns distinguishing tropical, temperate, and polar climates or wet versus dry regions
Analyze isoline maps showing temperature or precipitation patterns and identify gradients and anomalies

sub_topics.name: Choropleth Maps and Cartograms
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting thematic maps using color shading and distorted geography.
example_tasks: Analyze choropleth maps showing data by administrative units and identify spatial patterns and outliers in the data
Evaluate strengths (shows patterns) and limitations (depends on unit boundaries, larger areas visually dominate) of choropleth maps
Interpret cartograms where area is distorted to represent data values (population cartograms make densely populated areas larger)

sub_topics.name: Mental Maps and Spatial Cognition
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how people create internal representations of geographic space.
example_tasks: Draw a mental map of your neighborhood or city from memory and analyze what features you included versus omitted
Compare mental maps drawn by different people for the same area, noting how personal experience shapes spatial perception
Explain how mental maps can reflect biases, often overemphasizing familiar places while distorting or omitting unfamiliar areas

sub_topics.name: Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
sub_topics.short_description: Introduction to digital systems for capturing, storing, analyzing, and displaying geographic data.

sub_topics.name: Components of GIS
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding hardware, software, data, people, and methods that make up GIS.
example_tasks: Identify the five components of GIS: hardware (computers), software (GIS programs), data (spatial and attribute), people (users), methods (analysis techniques)
Explain how GIS differs from paper maps: digital data allows analysis, querying, updating, and display of multiple data layers
Research GIS software examples: ArcGIS (ESRI), QGIS (free, open-source), Google Earth Engine

sub_topics.name: GIS Data Layers and Attributes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how geographic features are organized in layers with associated information.
example_tasks: Describe how GIS uses layers (roads, rivers, buildings, land use) that can be turned on/off and combined for analysis
Explain the difference between spatial data (geometry: points, lines, polygons) and attribute data (characteristics: names, values, classifications)
Create a simple GIS data table linking spatial features (cities) with attributes (population, elevation, climate zone)

sub_topics.name: Vector versus Raster Data Models
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing discrete features versus continuous grid cells.
example_tasks: Define vector data as representing features with points, lines, and polygons (roads, rivers, boundaries)
Define raster data as grid of cells with values representing continuous phenomena (elevation, temperature, satellite imagery)
Compare strengths: vector data is precise and compact for discrete features; raster data better for continuous surfaces and analysis

sub_topics.name: Basic GIS Analysis Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Performing simple spatial analysis including buffering, overlay, and queries.
example_tasks: Explain buffer analysis: creating zones of specified distance around features (e.g., 1-mile buffer around schools for walking zones)
Describe overlay analysis: combining layers to find areas meeting multiple criteria (suitable land = correct soil AND slope AND not protected)
Use queries to select features meeting criteria: 'select all cities with population > 100,000 AND located in coastal counties'

sub_topics.name: GPS and Location Technologies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Global Positioning System and how location is determined using satellites.

sub_topics.name: GPS Principles and Operation
sub_topics.short_description: Examining satellite-based positioning using triangulation.
example_tasks: Explain how GPS determines location by measuring distance from multiple satellites (minimum 4) using signal travel time
Describe GPS satellite constellation: 24+ satellites in medium Earth orbit ensuring coverage anywhere on Earth
Calculate approximate location accuracy: civilian GPS ~5-10 meters, differential GPS ~1 meter, survey-grade ~centimeters

sub_topics.name: GPS Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Examining diverse uses of GPS technology.
example_tasks: Identify GPS applications: navigation (vehicles, hiking), tracking (delivery vehicles, wildlife), surveying (land boundaries), timing (financial transactions), precision agriculture
Explain how smartphone GPS combines satellite signals with cell tower and WiFi data for faster positioning
Research GPS use in geographic research: tracking animal migration, mapping archaeological sites, studying glacier movement

sub_topics.name: Global Navigation Satellite Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding alternatives to US GPS.
example_tasks: Identify GNSS systems: GPS (United States), GLONASS (Russia), Galileo (European Union), BeiDou (China)
Explain why countries develop independent satellite navigation: reducing dependence on US system, military applications, commercial opportunities
Describe how modern receivers use multiple GNSS simultaneously for improved accuracy and reliability

sub_topics.name: Remote Sensing and Satellite Imagery
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how information is gathered about Earth's surface from aircraft and satellites.

sub_topics.name: Principles of Remote Sensing
sub_topics.short_description: Examining electromagnetic radiation and how sensors detect reflected or emitted energy.
example_tasks: Explain how passive remote sensing detects natural radiation (visible light, infrared) reflected or emitted from Earth
Contrast with active remote sensing where sensors emit energy and measure return signal (radar, lidar)
Describe the electromagnetic spectrum showing visible light as small portion, with sensors detecting infrared, microwave, and other wavelengths

sub_topics.name: Types of Satellite Imagery
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing different satellite sensors and image types.
example_tasks: Compare true color images (visible light, looks natural) with false color images (include infrared, highlight vegetation, water, etc.)
Explain multispectral imagery capturing multiple wavelength bands versus hyperspectral capturing hundreds of narrow bands
Identify satellite systems: Landsat (land monitoring), MODIS (daily Earth observation), commercial satellites (high-resolution imagery)

sub_topics.name: Interpreting Satellite Imagery
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing satellite images to identify features and changes.
example_tasks: Identify features on satellite imagery using visual cues: color, texture, pattern, shape, size, shadow, association
Compare satellite images from different dates to detect changes: deforestation, urban growth, flooding, crop conditions
Analyze false color infrared images where healthy vegetation appears bright red (strong infrared reflection) while water appears dark

sub_topics.name: Remote Sensing Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Examining diverse uses of satellite and aerial imagery.
example_tasks: List applications: land use mapping, crop monitoring, forest health, urban planning, disaster response, climate monitoring, military surveillance
Explain how NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) measures vegetation health using red and infrared reflectance
Research how remote sensing monitors environmental change: glacier retreat, coral reef bleaching, air quality, sea level rise

sub_topics.name: Spatial Analysis Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Applying analytical methods to understand geographic patterns and relationships.

sub_topics.name: Nearest Neighbor Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Measuring whether points are clustered, dispersed, or random.
example_tasks: Calculate nearest neighbor index by comparing observed average distances between points with expected random pattern
Interpret results: index < 1 indicates clustering, index = 1 random, index > 1 dispersed pattern
Apply to real phenomena: retail stores (clustered), forest trees (often random), territorial animals (dispersed)

sub_topics.name: Network Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing transportation routes and finding optimal paths.
example_tasks: Use network analysis to find shortest route between two locations considering road distances
Calculate service areas showing all locations reachable within specified travel time from a facility
Optimize delivery routes visiting multiple stops to minimize total distance or time

sub_topics.name: Hotspot and Cluster Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying areas with statistically significant clustering of high or low values.
example_tasks: Define hotspots as areas with clusters of high values surrounded by high values (crime hotspots, disease clusters)
Identify coldspots as clusters of low values (low disease incidence, low temperatures)
Apply hotspot analysis to public health (disease outbreaks), crime (targeting police resources), environmental data (pollution sources)

sub_topics.name: Viewshed and Terrain Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Determining visible areas from specific locations using digital elevation models.
example_tasks: Perform viewshed analysis to determine what areas are visible from a mountaintop or tower location
Apply to cell tower placement (maximize coverage), wind turbine siting (minimize visual impact), military surveillance (maximize visibility)
Calculate slope and aspect (direction of slope) from digital elevation models for landslide risk or solar panel orientation

name: North America: Regional Geography
short_description: Comprehensive study of North American physical and human geography, including the United States, Canada, and Mexico. Students examine regional characteristics, resources, economy, and contemporary issues.

sub_topics.name: Physical Geography of North America
sub_topics.short_description: Examining major landforms, climate regions, and natural resources of the continent.

sub_topics.name: Major Landform Regions
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying North America's diverse physiographic regions.
example_tasks: Map major landform regions: Coastal Plains, Appalachian Mountains, Interior Plains, Rocky Mountains, Basin and Range, Pacific Coastal Ranges
Explain formation of mountain ranges: Appalachians (ancient, eroded fold mountains), Rockies (relatively young, fault-block mountains)
Describe the Great Plains as vast grassland region stretching from Canada through central US to Mexico

sub_topics.name: Climate Diversity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the wide range of climates across North America.
example_tasks: Map climate zones ranging from Arctic tundra (northern Canada) to tropical (southern Florida, Hawaii, parts of Mexico) to arid deserts (Southwest)
Explain why Pacific Coast has mild, wet climate (maritime influence, orographic precipitation) while interior has continental climate with extremes
Describe North America's vulnerability to severe weather: tornadoes (Great Plains), hurricanes (Atlantic/Gulf coasts), blizzards (northern areas)

sub_topics.name: Water Resources and River Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Examining major watersheds and water management issues.
example_tasks: Identify major river systems: Mississippi-Missouri (longest), Columbia, Colorado, Rio Grande, St. Lawrence, Mackenzie
Explain importance of Great Lakes as world's largest freshwater system (20% of Earth's surface freshwater)
Analyze water scarcity issues in American Southwest where demand exceeds supply from Colorado River and groundwater

sub_topics.name: Natural Resources
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the abundance and distribution of resources.
example_tasks: Map fossil fuel resources: oil and natural gas (Texas, Alaska, Alberta), coal (Appalachia, Wyoming), noting US and Canada are major producers
Identify mineral resources: iron ore (Minnesota, Quebec), copper (Arizona, Utah), gold, rare earth elements
Explain how resource wealth supported North American industrialization and economic development

sub_topics.name: Population and Settlement Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing population distribution, urbanization, and demographic characteristics.

sub_topics.name: Population Distribution Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding where North Americans live and why.
example_tasks: Identify population concentrations: Northeast Megalopolis (Boston-Washington), Great Lakes region, California coast, noting over 80% live in urban areas
Explain factors: most population near coasts or Great Lakes (water access), mild climate areas, regions with economic opportunities
