Explain guest worker programs: temporary labor migration without path to permanent residence (Gulf states, some European programs)
Analyze restrictive versus expansive policies and factors influencing approaches: labor needs, demographic concerns, political climate, security fears

sub_topics.name: Border Control and Enforcement
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding efforts to prevent unauthorized migration.
example_tasks: Describe border enforcement measures: physical barriers (walls, fences), surveillance technology, border patrol agents, interior enforcement
Analyze US-Mexico border militarization: increased enforcement making crossing more dangerous but not significantly reducing flows
Evaluate effectiveness and unintended consequences: pushing migrants to more dangerous routes, increasing smuggling fees, family separations

sub_topics.name: Irregular Migration
sub_topics.short_description: Examining unauthorized or undocumented migration.
example_tasks: Define irregular migration: entering or remaining in country without authorization, estimated ~10-12 million in US, millions in Europe
Explain pathways: overstaying visas (most common), unauthorized border crossing, using false documents
Analyze debates: economic impacts (low-wage labor, tax contributions versus public service costs), pathways to legalization, enforcement approaches

sub_topics.name: Restrictive Immigration Policies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding recent trends toward limiting immigration.
example_tasks: Identify restrictive measures: travel bans, reduced refugee admissions, increased deportations, border walls, detention centers
Analyze factors driving restrictions: economic anxiety, security concerns, cultural/identity fears, rise of nationalist political movements
Evaluate human rights concerns: family separations, detention conditions, pushbacks of asylum seekers, discrimination

sub_topics.name: Demographic Challenges
sub_topics.short_description: Examining population aging, youth bulges, and demographic imbalances.

sub_topics.name: Population Aging in Developed Countries
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding causes and consequences of aging societies.
example_tasks: Identify causes: declining fertility (below replacement 2.1), increasing life expectancy creating top-heavy age structures
Calculate old-age dependency ratios: fewer working-age people supporting growing elderly populations (Japan: 5:1 ratio in 1980 declining to 2:1 by 2030)
Analyze economic impacts: strained pension and healthcare systems, labor shortages, reduced economic dynamism, increased tax burdens

sub_topics.name: Policy Responses to Aging
sub_topics.short_description: Examining strategies to address aging population challenges.
example_tasks: Evaluate policy options: raising retirement age, encouraging higher fertility (family benefits, childcare), increasing immigration, cutting benefits, raising taxes
Research country approaches: Japan focuses on robotics and raising retirement age, France provides generous family benefits, Germany increased immigration
Analyze political challenges: seniors vote at higher rates resisting benefit cuts, difficult tradeoffs between competing priorities

sub_topics.name: Youth Bulges in Developing Countries
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding challenges and opportunities of large young populations.
example_tasks: Define youth bulge as unusually large proportion of population aged 15-29, common in sub-Saharan Africa, Middle East, South Asia
Explain dual potential: demographic dividend (if youth are educated and employed) or instability risk (if frustrated and unemployed)
Analyze link to political instability: youth bulges associated with higher risk of civil conflict when combined with economic stagnation

sub_topics.name: Sex Ratio Imbalances
sub_topics.short_description: Examining skewed sex ratios from gender selection.
example_tasks: Identify countries with abnormal sex ratios: China (114 males per 100 females at birth), India (110:100), driven by son preference and sex-selective abortion
Calculate that tens of millions of 'missing women' result from sex-selective abortion and neglect of female children
Analyze social consequences: marriage squeeze where men cannot find wives, increased trafficking, potential for social instability

sub_topics.name: Population Policies
sub_topics.short_description: Examining government interventions to influence population size and growth.

sub_topics.name: Antinatalist Policies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding efforts to reduce birth rates and slow population growth.
example_tasks: Analyze China's one-child policy (1979-2015): reduced fertility but caused aging, sex ratio imbalance, forced abortions, psychological impacts
Compare with India's voluntary family planning programs: sterilization incentives, contraception provision, education campaigns
Evaluate effectiveness and ethics: coercive policies raise human rights concerns, voluntary programs more acceptable but slower impact

sub_topics.name: Pronatalist Policies
sub_topics.short_description: Examining efforts to increase birth rates in low-fertility countries.
example_tasks: Identify incentives: cash payments for births (Russia, Poland), generous parental leave (Scandinavia), subsidized childcare, tax benefits
Research examples: Singapore's Baby Bonus scheme, Hungary's family support package, France's comprehensive family benefits
Evaluate limited success: most policies produce small increases (0.1-0.2 TFR points) and are expensive, underlying low fertility difficult to reverse

sub_topics.name: Family Planning Programs
sub_topics.short_description: Providing contraception and reproductive health services.
example_tasks: Explain how family planning programs help people achieve desired family size by providing contraception, education, maternal healthcare
Analyze success in reducing unintended pregnancies and fertility: Thailand's program helped reduce TFR from 6 to 1.5 in several decades
Identify that 218 million women in developing countries have unmet need for modern contraception, indicating need for expanded programs

sub_topics.name: Ethical Issues in Population Policy
sub_topics.short_description: Examining moral dimensions of government demographic interventions.
example_tasks: Debate whether governments should intervene in reproductive decisions versus viewing procreation as individual right
Analyze human rights concerns: forced sterilizations, restricted reproductive choices, discrimination against women
Compare reproductive justice framework emphasizing rights, access, and addressing root causes of high/low fertility rather than coercion

name: Globalization and Cultural Change
short_description: Study of cultural globalization, cultural identity, transnational connections, and debates over cultural homogenization versus diversity. Students examine how global flows of ideas, media, and people reshape cultures.

sub_topics.name: Defining and Measuring Globalization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding globalization as increasing interconnection and interdependence.

sub_topics.name: Dimensions of Globalization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining economic, political, cultural, and technological aspects.
example_tasks: Identify four dimensions: economic (trade, investment, production networks), political (international organizations, global governance), cultural (spread of ideas, values, practices), technological (communication, transportation)
Explain time-space compression: improved transportation and communication make world seem smaller, distances less significant
Analyze how globalization is uneven: some regions/people highly connected, others marginalized from global flows

sub_topics.name: Measuring Globalization
sub_topics.short_description: Using indices to quantify global connectedness.
example_tasks: Explain KOF Globalization Index measuring economic, social, and political globalization across countries
Interpret that most globalized countries tend to be small, wealthy European nations (Switzerland, Netherlands, Belgium), with large countries varying
Analyze trends: globalization generally increased 1990s-2008, slowed after financial crisis, faces current backlash and possible reversal

sub_topics.name: Drivers of Globalization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding factors enabling and promoting global integration.
example_tasks: Identify technological drivers: containerization (reduced shipping costs 90%+), jet aircraft, internet, mobile phones enabling real-time global communication
Explain political factors: trade liberalization, end of Cold War, international institutions (WTO, IMF), regional trade agreements
Describe economic factors: MNCs seeking global markets and production efficiencies, consumer demand for variety, capital mobility

sub_topics.name: Cultural Globalization Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how culture spreads and transforms globally.

sub_topics.name: Global Media and Communication
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding worldwide reach of media and entertainment.
example_tasks: Analyze dominance of Western (particularly American) media globally: Hollywood films, pop music, TV shows reach worldwide audiences
Explain one-way flow concerns: cultural products move primarily from developed to developing countries rather than bidirectional exchange
Identify counterflows: rise of regional media powers (Bollywood, K-pop, telenovelas), local content production, cultural hybridity

sub_topics.name: Global Consumer Brands
sub_topics.short_description: Examining worldwide recognition and presence of multinational corporations.
example_tasks: Identify ubiquitous global brands: Coca-Cola, McDonald's, Nike, Apple, Samsung available in most countries
Explain glocalization: global brands adapting products to local tastes (McDonald's offering vegetarian options in India, rice dishes in Asia)
Analyze brand symbolism: global brands representing modernity, westernization, cosmopolitanism, or for critics, cultural imperialism

sub_topics.name: English as Global Lingua Franca
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding English dominance in international communication.
example_tasks: Explain English as dominant language for international business, science, aviation, diplomacy, internet (~60% of websites)
Identify factors: British colonialism, US economic and cultural power, network effects (more speakers make it more useful to learn)
Debate impacts: facilitates global communication versus threatens linguistic diversity, advantages native English speakers

sub_topics.name: Diaspora and Transnational Communities
sub_topics.short_description: Examining dispersed populations maintaining connections to homelands.
example_tasks: Define diaspora as people dispersed from homeland maintaining collective identity and connections across borders
Research major diasporas: Chinese, Indian, Jewish, African, Irish, Mexican maintaining cultural practices, sending remittances, influencing homeland politics
Analyze how cheap communication and travel enable sustained transnational connections creating deterritorialized communities

sub_topics.name: Cultural Homogenization versus Heterogenization
sub_topics.short_description: Debating whether globalization creates cultural uniformity or diversity.

sub_topics.name: Cultural Homogenization and Westernization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining concerns about loss of cultural diversity.
example_tasks: Explain homogenization thesis: globalization spreading Western (particularly American) culture globally, eroding local distinctiveness
Identify evidence: global brands, English language, American media, Western fashion, fast food chains visible worldwide
Analyze 'McDonaldization' concept: standardization, efficiency, predictability, control characterizing not just restaurants but many global institutions

sub_topics.name: Cultural Imperialism Critique
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding criticisms of Western cultural dominance.
example_tasks: Define cultural imperialism as imposition of one culture on others through media, consumer products, economic power
Explain concerns: local cultures undermined, traditional values replaced with Western individualism and materialism, linguistic diversity threatened
Analyze French cultural protection efforts: quotas on French music/films, restrictions on English words, promoting Francophone culture

sub_topics.name: Cultural Heterogenization and Hybridization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how globalization may increase cultural diversity and mixing.
example_tasks: Explain heterogenization thesis: globalization creates more cultural mixing, hybridity, diversity rather than simple homogenization
Identify examples: fusion cuisine, world music, cultural appropriation and remixing, creolization creating new forms
Analyze how local cultures are not passive recipients but actively select, reinterpret, resist global influences maintaining distinctiveness

sub_topics.name: Glocalization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding adaptation of global products to local contexts.
example_tasks: Define glocalization as 'think global, act local' - adapting global products and practices to fit local cultures
Provide examples: McDonald's regional menu variations, MTV local language channels, IKEA furniture adapted to local tastes and spaces
Explain how MNCs strategically glocalize to succeed in diverse markets while maintaining global brand identity

sub_topics.name: Cultural Identity and Resistance
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how people and communities respond to globalizing forces.

sub_topics.name: Maintaining Cultural Identity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding efforts to preserve traditional cultures.
example_tasks: Identify preservation strategies: language revitalization programs, cultural festivals, traditional crafts, indigenous rights movements
Research examples: Welsh language revival, Maori cultural resurgence in New Zealand, Native American cultural preservation
Analyze tensions: desire to preserve traditions versus need to adapt to modern conditions, authenticity debates

sub_topics.name: Cultural Protectionism
sub_topics.short_description: Examining government policies protecting local culture from foreign influences.
example_tasks: Describe policies: quotas on foreign films/music, subsidies for local cultural production, restrictions on foreign ownership of media
Compare approaches: France's cultural exception policies, Canada's cultural protection, South Korea's screen quotas
Debate effectiveness: protectionism may preserve local culture but limit consumer choice, raise costs, and be difficult to enforce in digital age

sub_topics.name: Religious Fundamentalism as Resistance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding religious movements rejecting aspects of globalization.
example_tasks: Explain how some religious fundamentalisms arise partly as reaction against perceived Western cultural imperialism and secular modernity
Identify examples across religions: Islamic fundamentalism rejecting Western values, Christian fundamentalism opposing secularization, Hindu nationalism
Analyze complexity: fundamentalist movements selectively adopt modern technology (internet, social media) while rejecting cultural changes

sub_topics.name: Localism and Alternative Globalization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining movements promoting local community and sustainability.
example_tasks: Describe localism: emphasis on local food, local economy, local community connections as alternative to corporate globalization
Identify manifestations: farmers markets, local currency movements, transition towns, buy local campaigns, slow food movement
Evaluate as resistance to globalization: creating alternative economic relationships while often still connected to global networks

sub_topics.name: Digital Culture and Society
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how internet and social media transform culture and social interaction.

sub_topics.name: Social Media and Communication
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how platforms reshape social interaction and information sharing.
example_tasks: Analyze social media statistics: billions using Facebook, YouTube, WhatsApp, Instagram, TikTok creating unprecedented global communication
Explain impacts: enabling social movements (#MeToo, Arab Spring), creating echo chambers and polarization, spreading misinformation
Evaluate concerns: privacy erosion, addiction, mental health impacts (especially on youth), disruption of traditional media gatekeepers

sub_topics.name: Digital Divide
sub_topics.short_description: Examining unequal access to information and communication technologies.
example_tasks: Define digital divide: gap between those with and without access to modern ICT, correlating with income, education, age, urban/rural, developed/developing
Calculate global disparities: ~63% internet penetration globally but vast differences (95%+ in developed countries, <30% in least developed)
Analyze consequences: digital divide reinforces existing inequalities limiting access to information, education, economic opportunities

sub_topics.name: Internet Culture and Subcultures
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding online communities and cultural production.
example_tasks: Describe characteristics of internet culture: memes, viral content, participatory creation, anonymity, global reach, speed of diffusion
Identify how internet enables niche communities: fans, hobbyists, activists connecting across distances, creating subcultures
Analyze user-generated content transforming media: YouTube creators, Instagram influencers, TikTok trends competing with professional content

sub_topics.name: Digital Surveillance and Privacy
sub_topics.short_description: Examining data collection by corporations and governments.
example_tasks: Explain surveillance capitalism: tech companies monetizing user data through targeted advertising, creating detailed behavioral profiles
Identify government surveillance: mass data collection revealed by Snowden, censorship and monitoring in authoritarian states
Debate privacy concerns: personalization benefits versus loss of privacy, power asymmetries, potential for manipulation and discrimination

sub_topics.name: Globalization Debates and Critiques
sub_topics.short_description: Examining arguments for and against globalization.

sub_topics.name: Arguments for Globalization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding claimed benefits of global integration.
example_tasks: Identify economic benefits: increased trade, economic growth, poverty reduction (hundreds of millions lifted from poverty globally since 1990), consumer benefits (lower prices, variety)
Explain cultural benefits: exposure to diverse cultures, cosmopolitanism, global cooperation on challenges, spread of democracy and human rights
Cite evidence: global poverty declining (though inequality within countries often increasing), life expectancy rising, technology diffusion benefiting developing countries

sub_topics.name: Critiques of Globalization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding concerns about negative impacts.
example_tasks: Identify economic critiques: job losses in developed countries, exploitation of workers in developing countries, tax avoidance by MNCs, financial instability
Explain cultural critiques: homogenization, loss of local cultures, cultural imperialism, erosion of traditional values
List environmental concerns: race to the bottom on regulations, increased transportation emissions, pressure on resources, environmental injustice

sub_topics.name: Alter-Globalization Movement
sub_topics.short_description: Examining movements seeking alternative forms of globalization.
example_tasks: Define alter-globalization: seeking fairer, more sustainable globalization rather than rejecting global integration entirely
Identify demands: fair trade, debt relief for developing countries, environmental protections, labor rights, democratic governance of global institutions
Research movements: World Social Forum (alternative to World Economic Forum), anti-WTO protests, fair trade movement, global justice activists

sub_topics.name: Deglobalization and Backlash
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding recent trends toward nationalism and protectionism.
example_tasks: Identify signs of deglobalization: Brexit, Trump trade wars, rise of nationalist parties, reshoring initiatives, supply chain localization
Explain factors: economic anxiety from deindustrialization, immigration concerns, loss of national sovereignty, reaction to financial crises
Debate whether globalization reversal is occurring or just temporary pause, and whether it would benefit or harm economies

name: Development Geography
short_description: Analysis of economic development theories, development indicators, global inequalities, and pathways to development. Students examine why some countries are wealthy while others remain poor and evaluate development strategies.

sub_topics.name: Measuring and Classifying Development
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how development is defined, measured, and categorized.

sub_topics.name: Development Classifications
sub_topics.short_description: Categorizing countries by development level.
example_tasks: Compare classification systems: developed/developing, First/Second/Third World (outdated Cold War terms), Global North/South, OECD members
Explain World Bank income categories: low income (<$1,085 GNI per capita), lower-middle ($1,086-4,255), upper-middle ($4,256-13,205), high income (>$13,205)
Identify that categories are simplifications masking diversity within groups (upper-middle income includes both Turkey and China)

sub_topics.name: Economic Development Indicators
sub_topics.short_description: Using GDP, GNI, and related measures.
example_tasks: Calculate GDP per capita (PPP-adjusted) to account for cost of living differences enabling better cross-country comparisons
Explain GNI (Gross National Income) includes income from abroad, better reflecting prosperity than GDP for some countries
Identify limitations: don't capture informal economy, income distribution, quality of life, environmental sustainability, or non-market activities

sub_topics.name: Social Development Indicators
sub_topics.short_description: Measuring health, education, and wellbeing.
example_tasks: Identify health indicators: infant mortality rate (deaths per 1,000 live births), under-5 mortality, maternal mortality, life expectancy at birth
Describe education indicators: literacy rate, mean years of schooling, school enrollment rates, gender parity in education
Calculate access indicators: percentage with clean water, sanitation, electricity, internet, showing basic service availability

sub_topics.name: Composite Development Indices
sub_topics.short_description: Using multi-dimensional measures combining indicators.
example_tasks: Explain HDI (Human Development Index) combining life expectancy, education, and income into single score from 0-1
Interpret HDI categories: Very High (0.800+), High (0.700-0.799), Medium (0.550-0.699), Low (<0.550)
Compare countries with similar income but different HDI showing money alone doesn't determine wellbeing (Sri Lanka high HDI relative to GDP, Angola low)

sub_topics.name: Development Theories
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding competing explanations for uneven development.

sub_topics.name: Modernization Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding linear progression through development stages.
example_tasks: Explain Rostow's Stages of Growth: traditional society, preconditions for takeoff, takeoff, drive to maturity, high mass consumption
Identify assumptions: all countries follow same path, development requires Western-style institutions, traditional cultures are obstacles
Critique limitations: oversimplifies, ignores colonialism's impacts, assumes Western model universal, many countries stuck in early stages

sub_topics.name: Dependency Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how global economic structures perpetuate underdevelopment.
example_tasks: Explain core-periphery model: wealthy core exploits poor periphery through unequal exchange, extracting resources and cheap labor
Describe mechanisms: colonial legacy, terms of trade favoring manufactured goods over raw materials, debt, MNC profit repatriation
Evaluate: explains persistent poverty and inequality versus criticized as deterministic, ignoring agency, and some dependent countries (East Asia) developed

sub_topics.name: World-Systems Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding global capitalist system with core, semi-periphery, and periphery.
example_tasks: Explain Wallerstein's world-systems theory: global capitalist system with core (wealthy, specialized production), periphery (poor, extractive), semi-periphery (intermediate, like Brazil, Mexico)
Describe how semi-periphery can move upward (South Korea) or downward depending on global economic shifts
Analyze continued relevance: explains globalization's uneven impacts, persistent inequality, limits to autonomous national development

sub_topics.name: Neoliberalism and Market-Led Development
sub_topics.short_description: Emphasizing free markets, trade, and limited government intervention.
example_tasks: Identify neoliberal prescriptions: privatization, deregulation, trade liberalization, reduced government spending, foreign investment attraction
Explain Washington Consensus policies promoted by IMF/World Bank: fiscal discipline, tax reform, market-determined interest/exchange rates
Debate impacts: supporters cite growth in countries following policies, critics point to increased inequality, social service cuts, financial instability

sub_topics.name: Global Inequality
sub_topics.short_description: Examining disparities in wealth, income, and opportunity between countries and regions.

sub_topics.name: Global Wealth and Income Distribution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding massive disparities between rich and poor countries.
example_tasks: Calculate that richest 10% of countries have per capita incomes 50-100x higher than poorest 10%
Analyze wealth concentration: high-income countries with 16% of world population hold ~70% of global wealth
Explain absolute versus relative poverty: absolute (living below minimum survival level, ~10% globally), relative (poor compared to society's median)

sub_topics.name: Convergence versus Divergence
sub_topics.short_description: Debating whether income gaps between countries are narrowing or widening.
example_tasks: Explain convergence hypothesis: poor countries should grow faster than rich, eventually catching up
Analyze evidence: mixed picture - East Asian success stories versus persistent poverty in sub-Saharan Africa, divergence 1800-1970s, some convergence since 1990
Identify that China's rapid growth has driven global convergence in recent decades, but excluding China shows less progress

sub_topics.name: Poverty Traps
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding self-reinforcing cycles keeping countries poor.
example_tasks: Explain poverty trap mechanisms: low income → low savings → low investment → low productivity → low income continuing cycle
Identify additional traps: poor health reducing productivity, lack of education limiting opportunities, weak institutions discouraging investment
Describe how Jeffrey Sachs argues countries can escape through external aid providing 'big push' investment, though critics question aid effectiveness

sub_topics.name: Middle-Income Trap
sub_topics.short_description: Examining challenges countries face transitioning to high-income status.
example_tasks: Define middle-income trap: countries reaching middle-income but struggling to advance further as low-wage advantage lost but haven't achieved innovation-driven growth
Identify examples: many Latin American countries stuck in middle-income for decades, Southeast Asian countries attempting transition
Explain escape strategies: upgrading education, investing in R&D and innovation, improving institutions, moving up value chains

sub_topics.name: Obstacles to Development
sub_topics.short_description: Examining barriers preventing poor countries from developing.

sub_topics.name: Geographic and Environmental Obstacles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how physical geography affects development prospects.
example_tasks: Identify geographic disadvantages: landlocked countries facing high transport costs, tropical diseases, agricultural challenges from poor soils/climate
Explain Jeffrey Sachs' geographic determinism: tropical location correlates with poverty due to disease, soil quality, but critics note geography isn't destiny
Analyze resource curse: countries with abundant natural resources (oil, minerals) often have worse development outcomes due to corruption, Dutch disease, conflict

sub_topics.name: Colonial Legacy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how colonialism shapes current development patterns.
example_tasks: Explain extractive institutions: colonial powers created institutions designed to extract resources rather than promote broad-based development
Identify lasting impacts: arbitrary borders, ethnic tensions, economic structures oriented to former colonizers, missing industrial development
Compare settler colonies (US, Australia, Canada) that developed differently than extractive colonies (much of Africa, Latin America)

sub_topics.name: Governance and Institutions
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how political systems and institutions affect development.
example_tasks: Explain institutional quality importance: property rights, rule of law, contract enforcement, lack of corruption enabling investment and growth
Identify that weak institutions create uncertainty, enable rent-seeking, misallocate resources, discourage productive investment
Analyze democracy versus development debate: authoritarian countries can develop rapidly (China, Singapore historically) but democracy may ensure more inclusive, sustainable development

sub_topics.name: Conflict and Political Instability
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how violence and instability prevent development.
example_tasks: Calculate costs of conflict: deaths, refugees, infrastructure destruction, economic production disruption, investment deterrence
Identify conflict traps: poverty increases conflict risk, conflict perpetuates poverty creating vicious cycle
Research fragile states: countries with weak government control, ongoing violence, collapsed institutions (Somalia, Syria, Afghanistan) face extreme development challenges

sub_topics.name: Development Strategies and Pathways
sub_topics.short_description: Examining different approaches countries have taken to promote development.

sub_topics.name: Import Substitution Industrialization
sub_topics.short_description: Protecting domestic industries to promote industrial development.
example_tasks: Explain ISI strategy: high tariffs protecting infant industries, government investment in manufacturing, limiting imports to substitute domestic production
Identify countries using ISI: Latin America (1950s-1980s), India (until 1990s) with mixed results
Evaluate: created industrial base but often inefficient industries, rent-seeking, foreign exchange shortages leading most countries to abandon approach

sub_topics.name: Export-Oriented Industrialization
sub_topics.short_description: Promoting manufacturing for export markets.
example_tasks: Describe EOI strategy: producing manufactured goods for export, initially labor-intensive products (textiles, electronics) leveraging low wages
Analyze Asian Tigers success (South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore, Hong Kong): rapid industrialization and income growth through EOI
Identify enabling factors: educated workforce, infrastructure investment, government support, access to US market, though critics note authoritarianism and specific contexts

sub_topics.name: Microfinance and Bottom-Up Development
sub_topics.short_description: Providing small loans to enable entrepreneurship among poor.
example_tasks: Explain microfinance concept: small loans (microloans) to poor people without collateral, often targeting women, enabling small business creation
Research Grameen Bank model in Bangladesh: group lending with peer pressure for repayment, high repayment rates, poverty reduction claims
Evaluate debates: supporters cite empowerment and poverty reduction, critics question impacts, note high interest rates, and argue structural change needed

sub_topics.name: Foreign Aid and Development Assistance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding international aid flows and effectiveness debates.
example_tasks: Calculate that OECD countries provide ~$150 billion annually in Official Development Assistance, though only few meet 0.7% GNI target
Compare aid types: humanitarian (emergency relief), development (long-term projects), budget support (direct government funding)
Debate effectiveness: supporters cite specific successes (disease eradication, infrastructure), critics argue aid creates dependency, corruption, doesn't address root causes

sub_topics.name: Sustainable Development Goals
sub_topics.short_description: Examining global agenda for inclusive, environmentally sustainable development by 2030.

sub_topics.name: From MDGs to SDGs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding evolution of international development goals.
example_tasks: Describe Millennium Development Goals (2000-2015): 8 goals focusing on poverty, hunger, health, education with significant progress (poverty halved)
Explain Sustainable Development Goals (2015-2030): expanded to 17 goals with 169 targets covering economic, social, environmental dimensions
Compare scope: SDGs more ambitious and comprehensive, applying to all countries not just developing, emphasizing sustainability

sub_topics.name: SDG Implementation and Progress
sub_topics.short_description: Examining progress toward 2030 targets.
example_tasks: Identify goals at risk: hunger increasing, climate action insufficient, biodiversity loss continuing, inequality widening in many countries
Analyze COVID-19 impacts: setting back progress on poverty, health, education, widening gaps between countries
Evaluate financing challenges: achieving SDGs requires trillions in investment, far exceeding current aid levels, requiring private sector mobilization

sub_topics.name: Inclusive Development
sub_topics.short_description: Ensuring development benefits all groups in society.
example_tasks: Define inclusive development as growth reducing poverty and inequality, providing opportunities for all regardless of background
Identify excluded groups often left behind: women, ethnic minorities, disabled, rural populations, informal workers
Evaluate policies promoting inclusion: progressive taxation, social protection, anti-discrimination laws, targeted programs

sub_topics.name: Balancing Development and Environmental Sustainability
sub_topics.short_description: Addressing tensions between growth and environmental protection.
example_tasks: Explain environmental Kuznets curve hypothesis: pollution increases with early development, then decreases as countries become wealthier
Identify conflicts: developing countries prioritize poverty reduction over environmental protection, resent developed countries' calls for restrictions
Propose solutions: green technology transfer, climate finance, sustainable development pathways avoiding high-carbon development

name: Industrial and Post-Industrial Geography
short_description: Examination of manufacturing, service economies, and technological changes reshaping production and employment. Students analyze deindustrialization, industrial restructuring, and the shift to knowledge-based economies.

sub_topics.name: Industrial Revolution and Industrialization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the transformation from agricultural to industrial economies.

sub_topics.name: First Industrial Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Examining mechanization and factory system emergence in 18th-19th centuries.
example_tasks: Describe First Industrial Revolution (1760s-1840s) origins in Britain: textile mechanization, steam power, coal and iron, factory system
Explain why Britain first: coal deposits, capital availability, colonial markets, agricultural revolution freeing labor, property rights protecting innovation
Analyze social impacts: urbanization, working conditions, child labor, emergence of industrial working class, environmental pollution

sub_topics.name: Second Industrial Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding steel, electricity, chemicals, and mass production (1870s-1914).
example_tasks: Identify Second Industrial Revolution innovations: Bessemer steel process, electricity, petroleum, chemicals, internal combustion engine, assembly lines
Explain spread of industrialization: United States, Germany, Japan joining Britain as industrial powers
Describe organizational changes: corporations, vertical integration, scientific management (Taylorism), mass production (Fordism)

sub_topics.name: Newly Industrializing Countries
sub_topics.short_description: Examining rapid industrialization in late 20th century Asia and elsewhere.
example_tasks: Identify NICs: Asian Tigers (South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore, Hong Kong), followed by China, then Thailand, Malaysia, Vietnam
Explain industrialization strategies: export-oriented manufacturing, attracting FDI, investing in education and infrastructure, authoritarian development states
Analyze impacts: rapid economic growth, rising incomes, urbanization, but also inequality, labor exploitation, environmental degradation

sub_topics.name: The Global Factory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding fragmented production across multiple countries.
example_tasks: Explain global production networks: manufacturing stages distributed across countries based on comparative advantages (design in developed, assembly in developing)
Provide examples: iPhone designed in California, components from Japan/Taiwan/South Korea, assembled in China; automotive supply chains spanning continents
Describe role of containerization and information technology enabling coordinated global production

sub_topics.name: Manufacturing Location and Restructuring
sub_topics.short_description: Examining where manufacturing locates and how it has shifted globally.

sub_topics.name: Fordism and Mass Production
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding 20th century manufacturing organization.
example_tasks: Explain Fordism characteristics: assembly line production, standardized products, economies of scale, semi-skilled workers, vertical integration
Describe geographic pattern: large factories in industrial regions (US Manufacturing Belt, UK Midlands, Germany's Ruhr) with unionized workforces
Identify peak era: 1950s-1970s in developed countries when manufacturing employment maximized

sub_topics.name: Post-Fordism and Flexible Production
sub_topics.short_description: Examining shift to flexible, customized production systems.
example_tasks: Define post-Fordism: smaller batch production, product variety, just-in-time inventory, flexible specialization, outsourcing
Explain Japanese lean production model: eliminating waste, continuous improvement (kaizen), quality circles, supplier relationships
Analyze geographic implications: smaller plants, supplier networks, clustering for coordination, easier to relocate production

sub_topics.name: Offshoring and Outsourcing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding relocation of production to lower-cost locations.
example_tasks: Define offshoring (moving production abroad) versus outsourcing (contracting to external firms, may be domestic or foreign)
Identify drivers: labor cost differentials, avoiding regulations, accessing markets, tax advantages
Trace manufacturing shift: US/Europe → Japan/Korea (1970s-80s) → China/Southeast Asia (1990s-2010s) → potentially Africa, automation as alternative

sub_topics.name: Special Economic Zones and Export Processing Zones
sub_topics.short_description: Examining designated areas with favorable policies to attract manufacturing.
example_tasks: Explain SEZ/EPZ concept: designated areas with tax breaks, tariff exemptions, relaxed regulations, infrastructure to attract foreign investment and export manufacturing
Research examples: China's Special Economic Zones (Shenzhen), Mexican maquiladoras, numerous zones in developing countries
Evaluate: successful in attracting investment and creating jobs but criticized for labor exploitation, limited local linkages, tax revenue losses

sub_topics.name: Deindustrialization in Developed Countries
sub_topics.short_description: Examining decline of manufacturing employment and industry in formerly industrial regions.

sub_topics.name: Causes of Deindustrialization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding factors driving manufacturing decline.
example_tasks: Identify causes: automation reducing labor needs, offshoring to lower-cost countries, competition from imports, shift in consumer spending toward services
Explain that deindustrialization affects employment more than output (manufacturing production often increases while employment falls due to productivity gains)
Compare natural structural change (as economies develop, employment shifts to services) versus premature deindustrialization (developing countries losing manufacturing before fully industrializing)

sub_topics.name: Rust Belt and Industrial Decline
sub_topics.short_description: Examining impacts on formerly industrial regions.
example_tasks: Define Rust Belt: US Manufacturing Belt (Great Lakes, Northeast) experiencing industrial decline, plant closures, population loss since 1970s
Identify similar regions globally: UK Midlands, Germany's Ruhr Valley, northern France, showing common pattern of industrial region decline
Describe impacts: unemployment, poverty, population decline, urban decay, social problems, political resentment fueling populist movements

sub_topics.name: Industrial Restructuring and Adaptation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how former industrial regions attempt to reinvent themselves.
example_tasks: Identify restructuring strategies: attracting new industries (technology, services), promoting entrepreneurship, university partnerships, cultural amenities, brownfield redevelopment
Research success cases: Pittsburgh (technology, healthcare, education), Bilbao (culture, tourism), showing possible reinvention
Analyze challenges: requires substantial investment, not all places successfully transition, older workers struggle to retrain, populations may continue declining

sub_topics.name: Reshoring and Manufacturing Revival
sub_topics.short_description: Examining limited return of manufacturing to developed countries.
example_tasks: Explain reshoring motivations: rising wages in China, quality concerns, intellectual property protection, supply chain resilience, automation reducing labor cost importance
Identify that reshoring remains limited: only small fraction of offshored production returns, often as highly automated facilities with few workers
Debate manufacturing's future in developed countries: automation may enable competitiveness but provides fewer jobs than traditional manufacturing

sub_topics.name: Service Economy and Tertiary Sector
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the growing dominance of service activities in developed economies.

sub_topics.name: Growth of Service Sector
sub_topics.short_description: Examining expansion of tertiary activities.
example_tasks: Calculate that services represent 70-80% of GDP and employment in developed countries, showing post-industrial economy transition
Explain growth causes: rising incomes allowing more service consumption, manufacturing productivity gains freeing labor, outsourcing of business services
Distinguish productive services (business services, finance, consulting) from consumer services (retail, hospitality, personal services)

sub_topics.name: Service Sector Location Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding where different service activities locate.
example_tasks: Compare location patterns: consumer services (retail, healthcare) dispersed to follow populations versus producer services (finance, consulting) concentrated in major cities
Explain agglomeration in global cities: financial centers (New York, London, Tokyo) concentrating specialized business services
Identify services requiring face-to-face interaction (legal, consulting) versus those amenable to distance provision (call centers, data processing)

sub_topics.name: Service Offshoring
sub_topics.short_description: Examining relocation of service jobs to lower-cost countries.
example_tasks: Explain how telecommunications enable offshoring routine services: call centers, data entry, software development, financial processing
Identify major offshore service destinations: India (IT services, business process outsourcing), Philippines (call centers), Eastern Europe
Debate impacts: cost savings for firms versus job losses in developed countries, quality concerns, cultural differences affecting customer service

sub_topics.name: Gig Economy and Platform Work
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding app-based, on-demand service provision.
example_tasks: Define gig economy: short-term contracts or freelance work rather than permanent jobs, facilitated by digital platforms (Uber, DoorDash, TaskRabbit, Upwork)
Analyze worker classification debates: independent contractors (no benefits, protections) versus employees (entitled to benefits, minimum wage)
Evaluate flexibility benefits versus precarity concerns: workers value autonomy but face income instability, lack of benefits, algorithmic management

sub_topics.name: Knowledge Economy and Innovation
sub_topics.short_description: Examining economies based on information, technology, and intellectual capital.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Knowledge Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding information and innovation-based economic activity.
example_tasks: Define knowledge economy: economic activity where knowledge and information are primary factors of production, human capital is key resource
Identify knowledge-intensive sectors: software, biotechnology, pharmaceuticals, financial services, consulting, research, education
Explain shift from physical capital (factories, machinery) to intangible capital (patents, brands, data, expertise) as source of value

sub_topics.name: Innovation Clusters and Technopoles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding geographic concentration of high-tech industries.
example_tasks: Explain clustering benefits: skilled labor pools, venture capital, universities, knowledge spillovers, supplier networks, entrepreneurial culture
Identify major technology clusters: Silicon Valley (software, internet), Boston/Cambridge (biotech, robotics), Shenzhen (hardware), Bangalore (software)
Analyze why clustering persists despite digital connectivity: tacit knowledge sharing requires face-to-face interaction, serendipitous encounters valuable

sub_topics.name: Creative Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Examining industries based on creativity and cultural production.
example_tasks: Define creative industries: generating value from creativity, skill, talent including film, music, design, architecture, advertising, gaming, fashion
Explain geographic concentration in creative cities (Los Angeles, London, New York) due to agglomeration, cultural amenities, talent attraction
Analyze Richard Florida's creative class theory: attracting creative workers drives economic growth, though criticized for gentrification and inequality

sub_topics.name: Automation and Artificial Intelligence
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding technological changes displacing workers and transforming industries.
example_tasks: Identify jobs at risk of automation: routine manual work (manufacturing), routine cognitive work (data entry, basic analysis), potentially professional tasks (radiology, legal research)
Estimate that 30-50% of current jobs could be automated with existing technology, though implementation takes time
Debate impacts: pessimists fear mass unemployment, optimists expect new job creation, concerns about inequality as automation may favor high-skilled workers

sub_topics.name: Labor Geography and Working Conditions
sub_topics.short_description: Examining employment patterns, labor rights, and working conditions globally.

sub_topics.name: Global Labor Market Segmentation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding divisions in international labor force.
example_tasks: Describe dual labor market: primary sector (stable, good pay, benefits, career advancement) versus secondary sector (unstable, low pay, poor conditions)
Explain global divisions: high-skilled workers in developed countries earning high wages versus low-skilled workers in developing countries in precarious employment
Identify informal employment: over 60% of global workforce in informal sector lacking legal protections, social security, job security

sub_topics.name: Sweatshops and Labor Exploitation
sub_topics.short_description: Examining poor working conditions in developing country manufacturing.
example_tasks: Define sweatshops: workplaces with poor conditions (long hours, low pay, unsafe), common in garment, electronics, toy manufacturing
Research examples: Bangladeshi garment factories (Rana Plaza collapse killed 1,100), Foxconn factories assembling electronics with harsh conditions
Debate: employers argue providing better opportunities than alternatives, critics demand living wages and safe conditions

sub_topics.name: Labor Rights and Worker Organizing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding efforts to improve working conditions.
example_tasks: Explain union decline in developed countries: falling from 30%+ membership (1960s) to <20% now due to deindustrialization, anti-union policies, globalization
Describe challenges organizing in developing countries: government repression, employer hostility, export processing zones often prohibit unions
Identify alternative approaches: worker centers, NGO campaigns, consumer boycotts, corporate codes of conduct, though enforcement difficult

sub_topics.name: Corporate Social Responsibility
sub_topics.short_description: Examining voluntary business commitments to ethical practices.
example_tasks: Define CSR: companies voluntarily addressing social and environmental impacts beyond legal requirements
Identify CSR initiatives: codes of conduct, supplier audits, fair trade certification, sustainability reporting
Evaluate effectiveness debates: supporters see market-based improvement, critics argue voluntary measures insufficient without binding regulation and enforcement

name: Energy Resources and Geopolitics
short_description: Study of energy sources, consumption patterns, resource geopolitics, and energy transitions. Students analyze the geographic distribution of energy resources and international competition for control.

sub_topics.name: Global Energy Consumption Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding who uses energy and for what purposes.

sub_topics.name: Regional Energy Consumption
sub_topics.short_description: Examining geographic patterns of energy use.
example_tasks: Calculate that developed countries with ~17% of world population consume ~40% of energy, showing massive per capita disparities
Identify top consumers: China (largest total), United States (second largest, highest per capita among major economies), Europe, India (rising rapidly)
Compare per capita consumption: US ~300 GJ/person, Europe ~150, China ~100, India ~25, showing development-related differences

sub_topics.name: Sectoral Energy Use
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how energy is used across economic sectors.
example_tasks: Break down global energy use by sector: industry (~30%), transportation (~28%), residential/commercial (~30%), agriculture (~2%), with variations by country
Explain transportation sector almost entirely dependent on petroleum (95%+), making it difficult to decarbonize
Identify that electricity generation consumes ~40% of primary energy, losing ~60% in conversion, making efficiency improvements important

sub_topics.name: Energy Consumption and Development
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding relationship between energy use and economic development.
example_tasks: Explain strong correlation between energy consumption and GDP: economic growth historically required increasing energy use
Identify energy poverty: 800+ million people lacking electricity access, 2.6 billion using traditional biomass for cooking
Analyze decoupling efforts: developed countries attempting to grow economically while reducing energy use through efficiency, though absolute reductions difficult

sub_topics.name: Projected Energy Demand
sub_topics.short_description: Examining forecasts for future energy consumption.
example_tasks: Review projections showing global energy demand increasing 30-50% by 2050 under business-as-usual scenarios, driven by developing country growth
Explain that meeting growing demand while reducing emissions requires simultaneous efficiency improvements and renewable energy expansion
Identify uncertainties: economic growth rates, technology advancement, policy choices, behavior changes affecting projections

sub_topics.name: Fossil Fuel Resources
sub_topics.short_description: Examining oil, natural gas, and coal distribution and production.

sub_topics.name: Oil Reserves and Production
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding petroleum resource distribution.
example_tasks: Map oil reserves concentration: Middle East (48% of proven reserves), especially Saudi Arabia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, UAE, plus Venezuela, Russia
Identify top producers: US (recently largest due to shale oil), Saudi Arabia, Russia, Canada, China, with OPEC controlling ~30% of production
Explain reserves-to-production ratio: approximately 50 years of oil remaining at current consumption, though new discoveries, unconventional sources, and reduced demand complicate predictions

sub_topics.name: Natural Gas Reserves and Production
sub_topics.short_description: Examining distribution of natural gas resources.
example_tasks: Identify major reserves: Russia (largest), Iran, Qatar, Turkmenistan, United States (rising with shale gas)
Explain LNG technology enabling global trade: liquefying gas for tanker shipment expanding market beyond pipeline-connected regions
Analyze growing role as 'bridge fuel': cleaner than coal, abundant, but still fossil fuel emitting CO2, debates over locking in fossil infrastructure

sub_topics.name: Coal Reserves and Use
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding coal distribution and declining role.
example_tasks: Map coal reserves: widely distributed including US, Russia, China, India, Australia, South Africa with centuries of reserves
Identify major consumers: China (50% of global coal use), India, United States, though declining in many developed countries
Explain coal phase-out momentum: worst fuel for air pollution and CO2 emissions, developed countries closing plants, but still growing in some developing countries

sub_topics.name: Unconventional Fossil Fuels
sub_topics.short_description: Examining shale oil/gas, oil sands, and other resources.
example_tasks: Explain hydraulic fracturing (fracking): injecting fluid to fracture shale rock releasing trapped oil/gas, revolutionizing US production
Describe oil sands in Canada: petroleum mixed with sand requiring energy-intensive extraction, controversial due to environmental impacts
Analyze how unconventional resources extended fossil fuel availability but increased environmental concerns and costs

sub_topics.name: Renewable Energy Sources
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding clean energy alternatives and their geographic requirements.

sub_topics.name: Solar Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Examining photovoltaic and solar thermal technologies.
example_tasks: Explain solar PV technology converting sunlight directly to electricity: rapidly falling costs (90% decline since 2010) making it cost-competitive
Identify best locations: high insolation areas (deserts, tropical regions), though solar now viable in temperate zones
Describe challenges: intermittency (only during day, weather-dependent), storage needs, land requirements for large-scale deployment

sub_topics.name: Wind Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding wind power generation and geographic requirements.
example_tasks: Explain wind turbine operation: kinetic energy of moving air spins blades generating electricity, costs declined 70% since 2010
Identify prime locations: coastal areas, plains, mountain passes with consistent strong winds (Great Plains, North Sea, Patagonia)
Compare onshore wind (established, lower costs) with offshore wind (better wind resources, higher costs, less visual impact, growing rapidly)

sub_topics.name: Hydroelectric Power
sub_topics.short_description: Examining electricity generation from flowing water.
example_tasks: Explain hydropower as oldest large-scale renewable: dams store water releasing it through turbines, providing ~16% of global electricity
Identify major producers: China (largest capacity, Three Gorges Dam), Brazil, Canada, United States, with geography (precipitation, elevation) determining potential
Analyze environmental and social impacts: ecosystem disruption, fish migration barriers, sediment trapping, displacement of communities

sub_topics.name: Geothermal, Biomass, and Tidal Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding additional renewable energy sources.
example_tasks: Explain geothermal energy from Earth's heat: limited to tectonic boundaries and volcanic areas (Iceland, New Zealand, Philippines, Kenya)
Describe biomass energy from organic matter: burning wood, crops, waste for heat/electricity, sustainable if regrown but concerns about competition with food, pollution
Identify tidal and wave energy potential: predictable but geographically limited, technology still developing, high costs

sub_topics.name: Energy Geopolitics and Security
sub_topics.short_description: Examining political dimensions of energy resources and trade.

sub_topics.name: Petrostates and Resource Dependence
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding countries heavily dependent on oil/gas revenues.
example_tasks: Define petrostates as countries where oil/gas exports dominate economy and government revenues (Saudi Arabia, Russia, Venezuela, Kuwait, UAE, Qatar)
Explain Dutch disease: resource wealth causes currency appreciation harming other sectors, concentrating economy on resources
Analyze political effects: resource wealth can enable authoritarianism (oil funds repression, reduces need for taxation/representation), though not deterministic

sub_topics.name: OPEC and Oil Market Control
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
example_tasks: Explain OPEC formation (1960) to coordinate oil policies, control production levels, influence prices, with 13 members holding ~80% of reserves
Describe power dynamics: Saudi Arabia as swing producer, Russia coordination (OPEC+), conflicts between members (Iran-Saudi rivalry)
Analyze declining influence: US shale production, renewable energy, energy efficiency, price wars reducing OPEC's market control

sub_topics.name: Energy Import Dependence and Security
sub_topics.short_description: Examining vulnerability of countries relying on imported energy.
example_tasks: Identify major energy importers: Europe (dependent on Russian gas), Japan (imports ~90% of energy), China (growing import dependence), India
Explain energy security concerns: supply disruptions from conflicts, political tensions, price volatility affecting economies
Describe strategies to reduce vulnerability: diversifying suppliers, strategic reserves, domestic production, renewable energy, efficiency

sub_topics.name: Pipeline Politics and Chokepoints
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding geopolitical importance of energy infrastructure.
example_tasks: Map critical oil chokepoints: Strait of Hormuz (21% of global oil), Strait of Malacca (25% of traded oil), Bab el-Mandeb, Suez Canal
Analyze pipeline politics: Nord Stream (Russia-Germany bypassing Ukraine), Nabucco (failed EU attempt to reduce Russian dependence), Central Asian pipeline competition
Explain how control of energy infrastructure provides geopolitical leverage: Russia's gas cutoffs to Ukraine, US sanctions on pipelines

sub_topics.name: Energy Transitions
sub_topics.short_description: Examining shifts in dominant energy sources over time and future transitions.

sub_topics.name: Historical Energy Transitions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding past shifts in primary energy sources.
example_tasks: Trace energy transitions: wood/biomass (pre-industrial) → coal (Industrial Revolution) → oil (20th century) → natural gas (recent), each taking 50+ years
Explain why transitions are slow: infrastructure lock-in, capital investments, established industries resisting change, multiple sectors requiring coordination
Identify that old sources don't disappear: energy additions rather than substitutions, with fossil fuels still ~80% of global energy

sub_topics.name: Renewable Energy Transition
sub_topics.short_description: Examining current shift toward clean energy.
example_tasks: Calculate renewable energy growth: solar and wind capacity increasing exponentially, now cheaper than new fossil fuel plants in many locations
Identify leaders: Denmark (wind 50% of electricity), Norway (hydro 95%), Costa Rica (renewables 99%), showing feasibility
Analyze barriers: intermittency requiring storage/backup, grid integration challenges, political opposition from fossil fuel interests, developing country energy access needs

sub_topics.name: Energy Storage Technologies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding solutions to intermittent renewable energy.
example_tasks: Explain battery storage: lithium-ion costs declining 90% since 2010, enabling grid-scale storage, but still expensive for long-duration storage
Describe alternatives: pumped hydro storage (established, limited sites), hydrogen (promising but inefficient), thermal storage, compressed air
Identify that storage critical for high renewable penetration: managing solar/wind variability, enabling 24/7 clean electricity

sub_topics.name: Just Transition
sub_topics.short_description: Ensuring equitable impacts of shift away from fossil fuels.
example_tasks: Define just transition: ensuring workers and communities dependent on fossil fuels are supported during shift to clean energy
Identify affected groups: coal miners, oil/gas workers, regions economically dependent on fossil fuel industries (Wyoming, West Virginia, Alberta, coal regions globally)
Propose policies: retraining programs, economic diversification investments, social safety nets, involving affected communities in planning

sub_topics.name: Nuclear Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Examining fission power as alternative to fossil fuels.

sub_topics.name: Nuclear Power Technology
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how nuclear fission generates electricity.
example_tasks: Explain nuclear fission: splitting uranium atoms releases heat, boiling water to steam driving turbines, producing electricity without combustion emissions
Identify nuclear power's role: ~10% of global electricity, concentrated in developed countries (France 70%, US 19%, many countries phasing out)
Compare with renewables: baseload power, reliable, but expensive, long construction times, radioactive waste

sub_topics.name: Nuclear Accidents and Safety Concerns
sub_topics.short_description: Examining risks and major incidents.
example_tasks: Research major accidents: Three Mile Island (1979, limited release), Chernobyl (1986, worst disaster, large contamination), Fukushima (2011, tsunami caused meltdown)
Explain public fear despite relatively safe record: radiation fears, catastrophic accident potential, contrasted with actual deaths from fossil fuel pollution
Describe safety improvements: passive safety systems, better designs, stronger regulations, but concerns remain

sub_topics.name: Nuclear Waste Disposal
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding challenges of managing radioactive waste.
example_tasks: Explain nuclear waste problem: spent fuel remains dangerously radioactive for thousands of years, requiring long-term isolation
Identify lack of permanent disposal: most waste stored temporarily at reactor sites, few countries have permanent repositories (Finland's Onkalo)
Debate solutions: reprocessing (reduces waste but expensive, proliferation concerns), geological repositories (technically feasible but politically difficult)

sub_topics.name: Nuclear Energy Debate
sub_topics.short_description: Examining arguments for and against nuclear power.
example_tasks: Present pro-nuclear arguments: carbon-free, reliable baseload power, high energy density, proven technology that could rapidly decarbonize
Present anti-nuclear arguments: expensive, slow to build, safety risks, waste problem, proliferation concerns, renewables now cheaper
Analyze geographic patterns: some countries expanding nuclear (China, India), others phasing out (Germany, Belgium), some reconsidering (US, France)

name: International Trade and Transportation
short_description: Analysis of global trade patterns, supply chains, and transportation networks connecting the world economy. Students examine trade theories, trade agreements, and logistics systems.

sub_topics.name: International Trade Theories
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding economic explanations for why countries trade.

sub_topics.name: Absolute and Comparative Advantage
sub_topics.short_description: Examining David Ricardo's classical trade theory.
example_tasks: Define absolute advantage: ability to produce good more efficiently than another country (fewer inputs, lower cost)
Explain comparative advantage: even if one country has absolute advantage in all goods, both benefit by specializing in goods where they have greatest efficiency advantage
Calculate comparative advantage: use opportunity cost ratios to determine which goods each country should produce and export

sub_topics.name: Factor Endowments Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding trade based on resource availability.
example_tasks: Explain Heckscher-Ohlin theory: countries export goods using factors of production they have in abundance (labor, capital, land)
Provide examples: land-abundant countries export agricultural products, capital-abundant export manufactured goods, labor-abundant export labor-intensive products
Identify limitations: doesn't fully explain modern trade patterns (similar countries trade heavily with each other, intra-industry trade)

sub_topics.name: New Trade Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Examining economies of scale and product differentiation.
example_tasks: Explain how economies of scale drive trade: large-scale production reduces costs, creating advantages independent of resource endowments
Describe intra-industry trade: countries trading similar products (Germany exports BMWs to France, imports Renaults) due to consumer preferences for variety
Analyze implications: first-mover advantages, importance of market size, justification for some strategic trade policies

sub_topics.name: Global Trade Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Examining flows of goods and services internationally.

sub_topics.name: Growth of International Trade
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding expanding volume and share of global trade.
example_tasks: Calculate that world trade has grown faster than GDP for decades: trade as share of global GDP increased from 25% (1970) to 60%+ (pre-COVID)
Explain drivers: trade liberalization (lower tariffs), transportation cost reductions (containerization), communication technology, global production networks
Identify slowdown: trade growth decelerated after 2008 financial crisis, facing headwinds from protectionism, trade wars, pandemic disruptions

sub_topics.name: Trade Imbalances and Deficits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding persistent trade surpluses and deficits.
example_tasks: Identify major surplus countries: China, Germany, Japan, Russia (oil) exporting more than importing
Identify major deficit countries: United States (largest deficit), UK, France, India importing more than exporting
Explain imbalances: savings/investment differences, exchange rates, competitiveness, with debates over whether deficits are problematic

sub_topics.name: Trade by Product Category
sub_topics.short_description: Examining what is traded globally.
example_tasks: Break down global trade: manufactured goods (~70%), fuels/mining products (~15%), agricultural products (~9%), services (~20% and growing)
Identify most-traded manufactures: machinery, electronics, vehicles, chemicals, with increasing intra-industry trade in similar products
Explain services trade growth: digitalization enabling remote service provision (IT, business services, education), though still hindered by regulations

sub_topics.name: South-South Trade
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding growing trade between developing countries.
example_tasks: Calculate that South-South trade has grown from ~10% of world trade (1980s) to ~25% (2020s), driven by emerging economy growth
Identify China's role: major trading partner for developing countries, providing markets for commodities, exporting manufactured goods
Analyze implications: reducing dependence on developed countries, but also creating new dependencies, concerns about Chinese influence

sub_topics.name: Trade Agreements and Organizations
sub_topics.short_description: Examining institutions and agreements governing international trade.

sub_topics.name: World Trade Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding global trade governance institution.
example_tasks: Explain WTO role: establishing trade rules, negotiating trade liberalization, resolving disputes between member countries (164 members)
Describe principles: non-discrimination (MFN treatment), reducing barriers, transparency, allowing limited exceptions
Analyze criticism: perceived as favoring developed countries, dispute resolution ineffective, limited progress in Doha Round negotiations, US blocking appellate body

sub_topics.name: Regional Trade Agreements
sub_topics.short_description: Examining preferential trade arrangements between groups of countries.
example_tasks: Compare types: free trade areas (NAFTA/USMCA, removing internal tariffs), customs unions (adding common external tariff), common markets (allowing factor movement)
Identify major agreements: EU (deepest integration), USMCA, ASEAN, Mercosur, African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA)
Debate trade creation (efficiency gains from specialization) versus trade diversion (switching from efficient non-member to less efficient member)

sub_topics.name: Protectionism and Trade Barriers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding policies restricting imports.
example_tasks: Define tariffs (taxes on imports), quotas (quantity limits), subsidies (government support for domestic industries), technical barriers (regulations)
Explain protectionist arguments: protecting infant industries, national security, preventing job losses, retaliating against unfair practices
Analyze costs: higher consumer prices, reduced competition, inefficiency, retaliation from partners, though some strategic protection may be justified

sub_topics.name: Trade Wars and Conflicts
sub_topics.short_description: Examining escalating protective measures between countries.
example_tasks: Research US-China trade war (2018-): US imposed tariffs on Chinese goods citing unfair practices, China retaliated, tensions remain despite phase one agreement
Explain negative impacts: higher costs for businesses and consumers, supply chain disruptions, reduced trade growth, increased uncertainty
Identify historical precedent: Smoot-Hawley Tariff (1930) worsened Great Depression by triggering protectionist spiral, cautionary tale

sub_topics.name: Global Supply Chains
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding production networks spanning multiple countries.

sub_topics.name: Vertical Integration versus Outsourcing
sub_topics.short_description: Examining different production organization approaches.
example_tasks: Compare vertical integration (firm controls all production stages) with outsourcing (contracting production to external firms, often abroad)
Explain outsourcing motivations: cost reduction, focusing on core competencies, flexibility, accessing specialized capabilities
Identify risks: quality control challenges, intellectual property concerns, supply disruptions, ethical issues with contractor labor practices

sub_topics.name: Global Value Chains
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding production stages distributed across countries.
example_tasks: Describe value chain fragmentation: design, components, assembly, marketing spread across multiple countries based on comparative advantages
Explain smile curve: high value at design and marketing ends (in developed countries), low value in middle manufacturing stages (in developing countries)
Research upgrading challenges: developing countries trying to move from low-value assembly to higher-value activities (design, branding, R&D)

sub_topics.name: Just-in-Time and Lean Supply Chains
sub_topics.short_description: Examining efficiency-focused supply chain management.
example_tasks: Explain just-in-time principles: minimizing inventory, precise timing, reducing waste, originating with Toyota production system
Identify efficiency benefits: lower costs, faster response, reduced storage needs driving adoption across industries
Analyze vulnerability: COVID-19 pandemic, Suez Canal blockage, chip shortages showed fragility of lean global supply chains with no redundancy

sub_topics.name: Supply Chain Resilience and Reshoring
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding efforts to reduce supply chain risks.
example_tasks: Identify reshoring trends: some production moving back to home countries or nearshoring (moving closer) for resilience, speed, quality control
Explain friend-shoring: sourcing from politically aligned countries reducing geopolitical risks even if economically less efficient
Evaluate trade-offs: resilience through redundancy costs more than efficiency-optimized lean chains, requiring businesses to balance risks and costs

sub_topics.name: Global Transportation Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Examining systems moving goods internationally.

sub_topics.name: Maritime Shipping
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ocean transport dominating global trade.
example_tasks: Calculate that maritime shipping carries ~80% of global trade by volume, ~70% by value, making it foundation of global economy
Explain containerization revolution: standardized containers enabling efficient intermodal transport, dramatically reducing costs (90%+ since 1950s)
Identify major routes: Asia-Europe, Trans-Pacific (Asia-North America), intra-Asian, with Suez and Panama Canals as critical shortcuts

sub_topics.name: Major Ports and Shipping Hubs
sub_topics.short_description: Examining critical nodes in global maritime network.
example_tasks: Identify busiest container ports: Shanghai, Singapore, Shenzhen, Ningbo, Hong Kong, with Asia dominating
Explain hub-and-spoke system: major ports serving as transshipment centers where cargo is transferred between ships
Describe port competition: investments in capacity, efficiency, intermodal connections determining which ports capture traffic

sub_topics.name: Air Cargo and Express Shipping
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding high-value, time-sensitive goods transport.
example_tasks: Explain air cargo's role: carries <1% of trade by volume but ~35% by value, dominated by electronics, pharmaceuticals, perishables
Identify major air cargo hubs: Hong Kong, Memphis (FedEx), Louisville (UPS), Dubai, Shanghai, with dedicated cargo airports and integrated logistics
Describe express shipping: companies like FedEx, UPS, DHL providing door-to-door delivery, critical for just-in-time supply chains and e-commerce

sub_topics.name: Trucking and Rail Freight
sub_topics.short_description: Examining domestic and regional goods movement.
example_tasks: Explain trucking dominance for domestic transport: flexibility, door-to-door service, though energy-intensive and congestion-causing
Describe rail freight for bulk goods: coal, grain, containers, more fuel-efficient than trucks for long distances
Identify transnational rail: China-Europe freight trains (Belt and Road), North American rail networks showing regional integration

sub_topics.name: Logistics Technology and Tracking
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding information systems enabling global supply chains.
example_tasks: Explain how GPS, RFID tags, barcodes enable real-time tracking of shipments globally
Describe warehouse automation: robots, conveyor systems, algorithms optimizing storage and picking (Amazon fulfillment centers)
Identify emerging technologies: blockchain for supply chain transparency, autonomous vehicles (ships, trucks) for efficiency, drones for last-mile delivery

name: Geopolitics and International Relations
short_description: Advanced study of territorial conflicts, supranational organizations, and global power dynamics. Students analyze how geography shapes international politics and examine contemporary geopolitical tensions.

sub_topics.name: Power and Influence in International System
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different forms of power and how states exercise influence.

sub_topics.name: Hard Power: Military and Economic Coercion
sub_topics.short_description: Examining use of force and economic pressure.
example_tasks: Define hard power as coercing others through military force or economic sanctions to achieve goals
Identify examples: US military interventions, economic sanctions on Iran/North Korea/Russia, trade restrictions as pressure tactics
Analyze effectiveness and limitations: can compel behavior but costly, creates resentment, may backfire if target resists

sub_topics.name: Soft Power: Cultural and Ideological Influence
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding attraction and persuasion as power sources.
example_tasks: Define Joseph Nye's soft power concept: attracting others through culture, values, policies rather than coercion
Identify US soft power sources: Hollywood, universities, technology companies, democratic ideals spreading American influence
Compare with China's soft power efforts: Confucius Institutes, infrastructure investment (Belt and Road), though authoritarian governance limits appeal

sub_topics.name: Smart Power: Combining Hard and Soft
sub_topics.short_description: Examining strategic use of multiple power resources.
example_tasks: Explain smart power as effectively combining hard and soft power tools based on context
Provide examples: Marshall Plan (economic aid + political influence), NATO (military alliance + shared values)
Analyze why both dimensions matter: military/economic power provides capabilities, soft power provides legitimacy and willing cooperation

sub_topics.name: Global Power Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Examining distribution of power in international system.

sub_topics.name: Great Powers and Superpowers
