sub_topics.short_description: Identifying states with global influence capabilities.
example_tasks: Define great powers as states with military, economic, and political capabilities to influence events globally
Identify current great powers: United States (sole superpower), China (rising), Russia (declining but still influential), EU (economic giant, limited military/political unity)
Compare with regional powers having significant influence in their regions: India, Brazil, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Turkey

sub_topics.name: Unipolar, Bipolar, and Multipolar Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different international power configurations.
example_tasks: Compare system types: unipolar (one dominant power), bipolar (two rival powers), multipolar (several major powers)
Trace historical shifts: multipolar (pre-WWI), bipolar (Cold War US-USSR), unipolar (post-Cold War US dominance), emerging multipolar (US, China, EU, others)
Debate which system is most stable: some argue bipolar (clear rivalry structure), others multipolar (balance preventing dominance), empirical evidence mixed

sub_topics.name: Rising and Declining Powers
sub_topics.short_description: Examining power transitions and historical patterns.
example_tasks: Identify rising powers: China (economic growth, military modernization), India (population, growing economy), with concerns about challenging existing order
Recognize declining powers: Russia (GDP smaller than Italy despite nuclear arsenal), concerns about UK post-Brexit, questions about US relative decline
Explain power transition theory: tensions increase when rising power challenges established power, historically often leading to conflict (Thucydides Trap)

sub_topics.name: Middle Powers and Regional Leadership
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding states between great powers and small states.
example_tasks: Define middle powers as countries with moderate influence often pursuing multilateral diplomacy, norm promotion, bridge-building (Canada, Australia, South Korea, Turkey)
Explain niche diplomacy: middle powers focusing on specific issues where they can make contributions (Norway in peace negotiations, Canada in peacekeeping)
Analyze regional powers: Saudi Arabia in Gulf, Iran in Middle East, Brazil in South America, South Africa in Africa, competing for regional leadership

sub_topics.name: Territorial Disputes and Conflicts
sub_topics.short_description: Examining ongoing disputes over land and maritime territories.

sub_topics.name: Kashmir Dispute
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding India-Pakistan conflict over Kashmir region.
example_tasks: Explain origins: Kashmir's Muslim-majority population but Hindu ruler joining India at 1947 partition, Pakistan claiming territory, wars in 1947, 1965, 1999
Describe current division: India controls ~55% (Jammu & Kashmir, Ladakh), Pakistan ~30% (Azad Kashmir, Gilgit-Baltistan), China ~15% (Aksai Chin)
Analyze obstacles to resolution: nationalist sentiments in both countries, nuclear weapons raising stakes, insurgency and terrorism, China's interests complicating situation

sub_topics.name: Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
sub_topics.short_description: Examining disputes over territory between Israelis and Palestinians.
example_tasks: Trace historical development: Ottoman Palestine, British Mandate, 1947 UN partition, 1948 Arab-Israeli War, 1967 Six-Day War (Israel occupies West Bank, Gaza, Golan Heights)
Explain core issues: borders (1967 lines vs. Israeli settlements), Jerusalem status (both claim as capital), Palestinian refugees' right of return, security concerns
Assess two-state solution prospects: internationally endorsed but increasingly difficult with settlement expansion, political divisions (Fatah/Hamas), right-wing Israeli governments, US policy shifts

sub_topics.name: South China Sea Disputes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding overlapping maritime claims in Southeast Asia.
example_tasks: Map competing claims: China's nine-dash line claiming most of sea, versus claims by Vietnam, Philippines, Malaysia, Brunei, Taiwan based on EEZs
Explain strategic importance: $3+ trillion in trade passes through annually, fishing resources, potential oil/gas reserves, control of sea lanes
Analyze tensions: China building artificial islands with military facilities, US freedom of navigation operations, 2016 arbitration ruling against China (rejected), risk of conflict

sub_topics.name: Arctic Territorial Competition
sub_topics.short_description: Examining claims over Arctic Ocean as ice melts.
example_tasks: Identify Arctic states with competing interests: Russia, Canada, US, Norway, Denmark (Greenland) claiming continental shelf extensions
Explain growing interest: climate change opening navigation routes (Northwest Passage, Northern Sea Route), access to resources (oil, gas, minerals, fish)
Describe cooperation versus competition: Arctic Council facilitating dialogue but tensions over Russia's military buildup, sovereignty disputes, indigenous peoples' rights

sub_topics.name: Frozen Conflicts and Unrecognized States
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding unresolved conflicts with de facto territorial divisions.
example_tasks: Define frozen conflicts: ceasefires but no peace treaties, territorial disputes unresolved for decades
Research examples: Transnistria (Moldova), Abkhazia and South Ossetia (Georgia), Nagorno-Karabakh (Azerbaijan/Armenia conflict reignited 2020), Cyprus (divided since 1974)
Analyze why they persist: local actors benefit from status quo, great power interests preventing resolution, domestic political constraints

sub_topics.name: Supranational and International Organizations
sub_topics.short_description: Examining institutions where states cooperate and sometimes cede sovereignty.

sub_topics.name: United Nations System
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the primary global governance organization.
example_tasks: Explain UN structure: General Assembly (all 193 members), Security Council (5 permanent with veto: US, Russia, China, UK, France + 10 rotating), Secretariat
Describe UN roles: maintaining peace/security, human rights promotion, development assistance, humanitarian aid, international law
Evaluate effectiveness and limitations: successful in some areas (peacekeeping, disease eradication) but limited by member states' sovereignty, Security Council veto power, funding constraints

sub_topics.name: European Union Integration
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the deepest form of regional integration.
example_tasks: Trace EU evolution: coal/steel community (1950s) → common market (1960s-80s) → single market and currency (1990s-2000s) → political challenges (2010s-present)
Explain integration features: free movement of goods/services/capital/people, common currency (euro in 20 countries), European Parliament, European Court of Justice
Analyze tensions: sovereignty concerns, north-south economic divisions, east-west political differences, migration disagreements, Brexit showing integration can reverse

sub_topics.name: Other Regional Organizations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding regional cooperation and integration efforts globally.
example_tasks: Compare regional organizations: African Union (55 members), ASEAN (10 Southeast Asian), Arab League (22), Organization of American States (35)
Explain varying integration levels: some focus on economic cooperation, others add political/security dimensions, none match EU's supranationalism
Evaluate effectiveness: regional organizations can address local issues, but often weak due to limited resources, political divisions among members, sovereignty concerns

sub_topics.name: International Courts and Law
sub_topics.short_description: Examining legal institutions in international system.
example_tasks: Identify international courts: International Court of Justice (state disputes), International Criminal Court (individual war crimes), regional courts (European Court of Human Rights)
Explain challenges enforcing international law: no global police force, powerful states often ignore rulings (US, Russia, China not ICC parties), compliance voluntary
Debate sovereignty versus accountability: international courts potentially hold states/individuals accountable but some see as infringing on national sovereignty

sub_topics.name: Contemporary Geopolitical Tensions
sub_topics.short_description: Examining current flashpoints and rivalries shaping international relations.

sub_topics.name: US-China Strategic Competition
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the defining geopolitical rivalry of the 21st century.
example_tasks: Identify competition dimensions: economic (trade, technology leadership), military (Taiwan, South China Sea), ideological (democracy vs. authoritarianism), technological (5G, AI, semiconductors)
Explain US concerns: China's economic rise, military modernization, assertiveness in region, human rights issues, technology theft, threatening US global leadership
Analyze China's perspective: reclaiming historical position, US trying to contain rise, defending sovereignty and security interests, right to different political system

sub_topics.name: Russia-West Relations
sub_topics.short_description: Examining renewed tensions after post-Cold War cooperation period.
example_tasks: Trace deteriorating relations: NATO expansion eastward (Russian concern), 2008 Georgia war, 2014 Ukraine crisis (Crimea annexation), 2022 full-scale Ukraine invasion
Explain Russian grievances: feeling encircled by NATO, loss of great power status, Western interference in post-Soviet space, NATO's eastward expansion
Identify Western concerns: Russian aggression against neighbors, election interference, cyber attacks, support for authoritarian regimes, nuclear threats

sub_topics.name: Middle East Geopolitics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding complex regional rivalries and conflicts.
example_tasks: Identify key rivalries: Iran vs. Saudi Arabia (Shia vs. Sunni, regional hegemony), Iran vs. Israel, Turkey's regional ambitions, proxy conflicts in Yemen, Syria, Iraq
Explain sectarian dimension: Sunni-Shia divide overlaying geopolitical competition, though not purely religious
Analyze external powers' roles: US traditionally supporting Israel and Gulf states, Russia backing Assad in Syria, China increasing economic presence, shifting alignments

sub_topics.name: Taiwan Strait Tensions
sub_topics.short_description: Examining potential flashpoint between China and US.
example_tasks: Explain status quo: China claims Taiwan as province, Taiwan operates as de facto independent state, US strategically ambiguous about defending Taiwan
Identify increasing tensions: Chinese military activities, Xi Jinping emphasizing reunification, growing Taiwanese distinct identity, US support for Taiwan
Analyze war risks: Taiwan Strait one of world's most dangerous potential conflicts, could involve US and China, massive economic disruptions (semiconductor production)

sub_topics.name: Korean Peninsula Security
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the frozen conflict and nuclear proliferation concerns.
example_tasks: Explain division since Korean War (1950-53): armistice but no peace treaty, North Korea authoritarian with nuclear weapons, South Korea democratic and prosperous
Describe North Korean nuclear program: developing weapons and missiles despite sanctions, using nuclear capability for regime security and coercive diplomacy
Evaluate reunification prospects: economically beneficial but politically complex, China concerned about unified pro-US Korea on border, South Korea uncertain about absorption costs

sub_topics.name: Weapons Proliferation and Arms Control
sub_topics.short_description: Examining spread of dangerous weapons and efforts to limit them.

sub_topics.name: Nuclear Weapons Proliferation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding spread of nuclear weapons beyond original nuclear powers.
example_tasks: Identify nuclear weapons states: US, Russia, UK, France, China (NPT-recognized), India, Pakistan, Israel (undeclared), North Korea (withdrawn from NPT)
Explain Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT): nuclear states pledge disarmament, non-nuclear states forgo weapons, all have right to peaceful nuclear energy
Analyze proliferation risks: Iran's nuclear program (JCPOA attempted to limit), concerns about Pakistan's arsenal security, North Korea's development, potential future proliferators

sub_topics.name: Conventional Arms Trade
sub_topics.short_description: Examining global trade in conventional weapons.
example_tasks: Identify major arms exporters: US (largest), Russia, France, Germany, China supplying weapons globally
Explain motivations: exporters gain revenue and influence, importers acquire capabilities, alliances reinforced through arms sales
Analyze concerns: arms fueling conflicts, human rights abuses by recipients, destabilization, though arms embargoes can be ineffective

sub_topics.name: Arms Control and Disarmament
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding treaties limiting weapons.
example_tasks: Research Cold War arms control: SALT, START treaties reducing US-Russia nuclear arsenals from 60,000+ combined to ~12,000
Explain recent treaty erosion: INF Treaty collapsed (2019), Open Skies Treaty (US withdrew 2020), New START extended but uncertain future
Identify other treaties: Chemical Weapons Convention, Biological Weapons Convention, Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (not entered into force), showing mixed success

name: Advanced GIS and Spatial Analysis
short_description: Application of Geographic Information Systems for complex spatial analysis including modeling, network analysis, and spatial statistics. Students develop advanced GIS skills for professional applications.

sub_topics.name: Advanced GIS Data Management
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding complex data structures and management techniques.

sub_topics.name: Geodatabases and Data Models
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing spatial data in relational database structures.
example_tasks: Compare geodatabase types: file geodatabase (single-user), enterprise geodatabase (multi-user, versioned), explaining appropriate uses
Design normalized database schema for geographic data with feature classes, tables, relationships, domains
Implement topology rules ensuring data quality: no gaps/overlaps in parcels, lines connecting at nodes, polygons contained within boundaries

sub_topics.name: Coordinate Systems and Projections
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and managing different spatial reference systems.
example_tasks: Distinguish geographic coordinate systems (angular units on spheroid) from projected coordinate systems (Cartesian coordinates on plane)
Select appropriate projections for different purposes: equal-area (density analysis), conformal (navigation), equidistant (distance measurement)
Transform data between coordinate systems, understanding how distortion patterns change with different projections

sub_topics.name: Metadata Standards and Documentation
sub_topics.short_description: Creating comprehensive documentation of spatial data.
example_tasks: Create FGDC or ISO metadata documenting data source, accuracy, currency, processing steps, coordinate system, attributes
Explain importance of metadata: enables data discovery, informs appropriate use, ensures reproducibility, documents lineage
Evaluate metadata completeness using standards checklists, identifying required versus optional elements

sub_topics.name: Advanced Spatial Analysis Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Applying sophisticated analytical methods to geographic problems.

sub_topics.name: Overlay Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Combining multiple spatial datasets to identify areas meeting criteria.
example_tasks: Perform union overlay retaining all features and attributes from input layers to analyze composite patterns
Use intersect overlay to find areas where multiple conditions overlap (suitable habitat = correct vegetation AND elevation AND distance from water)
Apply erase overlay removing unwanted areas (developable land = total area MINUS protected areas MINUS wetlands)

sub_topics.name: Proximity and Distance Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Measuring and analyzing spatial relationships based on distance.
example_tasks: Create multiple ring buffers around features showing distance zones (0-1 mile, 1-3 miles, 3-5 miles from hazard)
Calculate Euclidean distance surfaces showing straight-line distance to nearest feature
Measure cost-distance considering terrain, barriers, varying travel costs rather than simple distance

sub_topics.name: Surface Analysis and Terrain Modeling
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing continuous surfaces and elevation data.
example_tasks: Derive slope, aspect, hillshade, curvature from digital elevation models for terrain characterization
Perform viewshed analysis identifying visible areas from observation points for tower siting or visibility impact assessment
Calculate cut-and-fill volumes for construction projects by comparing existing and proposed elevation surfaces

sub_topics.name: Density and Interpolation Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Creating continuous surfaces from point data.
example_tasks: Calculate kernel density of point features (crime incidents, disease cases) creating smooth continuous surface showing concentration
Apply IDW (Inverse Distance Weighting) interpolation to estimate values at unmeasured locations based on nearby samples
Use kriging interpolation accounting for spatial autocorrelation and providing uncertainty estimates for predictions

sub_topics.name: Advanced Network Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing transportation and utility networks for routing and allocation.

sub_topics.name: Routing and Shortest Path Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Finding optimal routes through networks.
example_tasks: Calculate shortest path between two points considering distance, time, or other impedance factors (traffic, elevation change)
Find closest facility determining which service location is nearest to each demand point
Generate travel time isochrones showing areas reachable within specified times from origin

sub_topics.name: Service Area and Coverage Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Determining coverage and accessibility of facilities.
example_tasks: Create service areas showing regions reachable within distance or time thresholds from fire stations, hospitals, or other facilities
Identify underserved areas where population lacks adequate access to services based on travel time standards
Optimize facility locations to maximize population coverage within acceptable travel times

sub_topics.name: Vehicle Routing Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Optimizing routes for multiple vehicles and stops.
example_tasks: Solve vehicle routing problem minimizing total distance traveled while visiting all required stops (delivery routes)
Apply traveling salesman problem finding shortest route visiting all locations once and returning to origin
Optimize school bus routes minimizing total travel time while respecting capacity and maximum ride time constraints

sub_topics.name: Location-Allocation Modeling
sub_topics.short_description: Optimizing facility placement to minimize travel or maximize coverage.
example_tasks: Apply p-median model locating p facilities to minimize average distance from demand points
Use maximal coverage model placing facilities to maximize population served within distance standard
Solve capacitated location-allocation considering facility capacity constraints and demand volumes

sub_topics.name: Advanced Spatial Statistics
sub_topics.short_description: Applying statistical methods accounting for spatial relationships.

sub_topics.name: Spatial Autocorrelation Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Measuring degree of clustering or dispersion in spatial patterns.
example_tasks: Calculate Global Moran's I statistic testing whether similar values cluster spatially or show random distribution
Apply Local Moran's I (LISA) identifying specific locations of significant clustering (hotspots/coldspots)
Interpret spatial autocorrelation results: positive (clustering), negative (dispersion), zero (random)

sub_topics.name: Hot Spot Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying statistically significant spatial clusters.
example_tasks: Perform Getis-Ord Gi* analysis identifying locations with statistically significant high values (hot spots) or low values (cold spots)
Determine appropriate distance band for spatial relationships based on data characteristics and geographic context
Apply hot spot analysis to disease incidence, crime, poverty, or environmental variables identifying priority intervention areas

sub_topics.name: Spatial Regression Models
sub_topics.short_description: Regression analysis accounting for spatial dependence.
example_tasks: Diagnose spatial autocorrelation in regression residuals using Moran's I, indicating need for spatial regression
Apply spatial lag models including spatially lagged dependent variable (neighboring values affect outcomes)
Use spatial error models accounting for spatial autocorrelation in error terms

sub_topics.name: Geostatistics and Kriging
sub_topics.short_description: Advanced interpolation methods based on spatial correlation structure.
example_tasks: Create semivariogram modeling spatial correlation as function of distance to inform kriging interpolation
Perform ordinary kriging providing best linear unbiased predictions with uncertainty estimates
Apply cokriging using additional correlated variables to improve prediction accuracy

sub_topics.name: 3D GIS and Temporal Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Working with three-dimensional data and analyzing change over time.

sub_topics.name: 3D Visualization and Modeling
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and displaying three-dimensional geographic representations.
example_tasks: Drape 2D data over digital elevation models creating 3D perspective views of terrain with overlaid features
Extrude building footprints to height values creating 3D city models for visualization and analysis
Generate fly-through animations navigating through 3D landscapes for presentation or planning visualization

sub_topics.name: LiDAR and Point Cloud Data
sub_topics.short_description: Processing laser scanning data for detailed terrain and feature extraction.
example_tasks: Classify LiDAR point clouds into ground, vegetation, buildings, and other categories using automated algorithms
Generate high-resolution digital elevation models from LiDAR ground points for detailed terrain analysis
Extract building footprints and heights from LiDAR point clouds for 3D city modeling

sub_topics.name: Temporal GIS and Change Detection
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing geographic data across time to detect changes.
example_tasks: Perform change detection comparing satellite images or datasets from different dates to identify land use changes, deforestation, or urban growth
Create space-time cubes visualizing phenomena varying across space and time (disease spread, traffic patterns)
Apply time series analysis to geographic data examining trends, seasonality, and anomalies in spatial phenomena

sub_topics.name: Spatiotemporal Modeling
sub_topics.short_description: Modeling processes that vary across both space and time.
example_tasks: Build diffusion models simulating spread of phenomena (disease, information, innovations) across space over time
Create agent-based models simulating individual entities moving and interacting in space producing emergent patterns
Develop cellular automata models where cell states change based on neighboring cells' states representing dynamic spatial processes

sub_topics.name: Professional GIS Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Applying GIS to real-world problems in various domains.

sub_topics.name: Environmental GIS Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Using GIS for environmental analysis and management.
example_tasks: Perform habitat suitability analysis identifying areas meeting species' environmental requirements
Model watershed boundaries and flow accumulation for hydrology and water quality studies
Assess environmental impact by overlaying proposed development with sensitive areas (wetlands, endangered species habitat)

sub_topics.name: Public Health and Epidemiology GIS
sub_topics.short_description: Applying spatial analysis to health data.
example_tasks: Map disease incidence rates by geographic unit identifying spatial disparities and clusters
Analyze accessibility to healthcare facilities calculating travel times and underserved populations
Investigate environmental health risks correlating pollution sources with disease patterns

sub_topics.name: Urban Planning and Smart Cities
sub_topics.short_description: Using GIS for urban analysis and planning.
example_tasks: Conduct site suitability analysis for development identifying locations meeting multiple criteria
Analyze urban growth patterns using historical imagery and predict future expansion
Optimize public transit routes and schedules using origin-destination data and network analysis

sub_topics.name: Emergency Management and Disaster Response
sub_topics.short_description: Applying GIS to hazard assessment and emergency response.
example_tasks: Create hazard vulnerability maps identifying populations and infrastructure at risk from floods, earthquakes, or other hazards
Plan evacuation routes using network analysis considering capacity and population distribution
Support disaster response with real-time mapping of affected areas, damage assessment, and resource allocation

name: Europe, Asia, and Africa: Comparative Regional Geography
short_description: Comparative analysis of Eurasian and African geographic patterns examining physical geography, population, culture, economy, and contemporary issues across world's largest landmasses.

sub_topics.name: Europe: Regional Geography
sub_topics.short_description: Examining physical and human geography of Europe.

sub_topics.name: Physical Geography of Europe
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Europe's diverse landscapes and climates.
example_tasks: Map major landforms: Alps (highest mountains), Pyrenees, Carpathians, Scandinavian Mountains, North European Plain, Mediterranean peninsulas
Explain Europe's moderate climate despite northern latitude: North Atlantic Current warming western areas, maritime influence tempering extremes
Identify major rivers: Danube, Rhine, Volga serving as transportation corridors and national boundaries

sub_topics.name: European Integration and EU
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Europe's unprecedented regional integration.
example_tasks: Trace European integration from post-WWII cooperation to current 27-member EU with single market, common currency, free movement
Explain benefits: peace after centuries of war, economic prosperity, environmental cooperation, global influence
Analyze challenges: sovereignty tensions, economic disparities (core vs. periphery), migration disagreements, Brexit showing limits

sub_topics.name: European Economic Geography
sub_topics.short_description: Examining Europe's advanced, service-based economies.
example_tasks: Identify economic core: Blue Banana/Golden Triangle from London through Low Countries, Germany, Northern Italy with highest wealth and productivity
Compare northern/western European prosperity with southern/eastern challenges: Greece/Italy debt crises, post-communist transition struggles
Describe European social model: strong welfare states, labor protections, universal healthcare, work-life balance valued

sub_topics.name: Contemporary European Issues
sub_topics.short_description: Examining current challenges facing Europe.
example_tasks: Analyze migration and refugee issues: 2015 refugee crisis, integration challenges, rise of anti-immigrant parties
Explain demographic challenges: aging populations, low fertility, labor shortages requiring immigration despite political resistance
Describe euro crisis: common currency without fiscal union created problems during 2008-2012 crisis, continuing north-south tensions

sub_topics.name: Russia and Central Asia
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the world's largest country and former Soviet republics.

sub_topics.name: Physical Geography of Russia
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Russia's vast territory and harsh climate.
example_tasks: Map Russia's size: largest country (11 time zones, 17 million km²), spanning Europe and Asia, with varied terrain from plains to mountains
Explain continental climate: cold winters (interior coldest on Earth), short summers, permafrost covering much of Siberia
Identify major rivers: Volga, Ob, Yenisei, Lena flowing to Arctic and Pacific, frozen much of year

sub_topics.name: Russia's Resource Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding dependence on oil, gas, and minerals.
example_tasks: Explain resource abundance: world's largest natural gas reserves, major oil producer, vast minerals, but resource-dependent economy vulnerable to price fluctuations
Describe geographic challenges: resources often in remote Siberia requiring expensive infrastructure, harsh climate increasing extraction costs
Analyze economic structure: manufacturing declined post-Soviet, now heavily dependent on energy exports, limited economic diversification

sub_topics.name: Central Asian Republics
sub_topics.short_description: Examining former Soviet republics in Central Asia.
example_tasks: Identify five 'stans': Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, independent since 1991 Soviet collapse
Describe challenges: landlocked positions, water disputes (Aral Sea disaster), authoritarian governments, economic underdevelopment, ethnic tensions
Analyze competition for influence: Russia maintaining ties, China's Belt and Road investments, Western interest limited

sub_topics.name: East Asia: China, Japan, Korea
sub_topics.short_description: Examining major East Asian economies and cultures.

sub_topics.name: China's Rise
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding China's rapid economic growth and global influence.
example_tasks: Explain reform era since 1978: market reforms under communist political system, world's second-largest economy, 800+ million lifted from poverty
Describe geographic challenges: uneven development (prosperous coast vs. poor interior), pollution, water scarcity, aging population
Analyze Belt and Road Initiative: massive infrastructure investment across Asia, Africa, Europe expanding Chinese influence

sub_topics.name: Japan's Development Model
sub_topics.short_description: Examining post-war economic miracle and current challenges.
example_tasks: Trace post-WWII development: devastated 1945, rapid industrialization, world's second-largest economy by 1980s, export-oriented growth
Identify current challenges: aging population (29% over 65), stagnant growth since 1990s, massive debt, labor shortages
Describe cultural factors: homogeneous society, high education, strong work ethic, technological innovation

sub_topics.name: Korean Peninsula
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing divided Koreas.
example_tasks: Compare South Korea's development (democratic, 11th largest economy, technology leader) with North Korea's isolation (authoritarian, impoverished, militarized)
Explain division origins: Japanese colonial rule, Soviet/US occupation, Korean War (1950-53), armistice but no peace treaty
Analyze reunification challenges: North Korean nuclear weapons, economic disparities, political systems incompatibility, Chinese/US interests

sub_topics.name: South and Southeast Asia
sub_topics.short_description: Examining populous and diverse regions.

sub_topics.name: India's Development
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding world's largest democracy and emerging economy.
example_tasks: Explain India's characteristics: 1.4 billion people (most populous), democracy with federal system, diverse languages/religions, rapidly growing economy
Identify challenges: poverty (still 10% in extreme poverty), inequality, inadequate infrastructure, water scarcity, air pollution
Describe economic reforms: liberalization since 1991, IT services strength, manufacturing push, but agriculture still employs 40%

sub_topics.name: Southeast Asian Diversity
sub_topics.short_description: Examining ASEAN region's varied development.
example_tasks: Compare development levels: Singapore (high-income), Thailand/Malaysia (middle-income industrializing), Myanmar/Cambodia (low-income agricultural)
Explain geographic diversity: mainland versus maritime, ethnic and religious complexity, colonial legacies (British, French, Dutch)
Describe ASEAN: 10-member economic and political grouping promoting regional cooperation and integration

sub_topics.name: Middle East and North Africa
sub_topics.short_description: Examining oil-rich but conflict-affected region.

sub_topics.name: Physical Geography of MENA
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding arid climate and water scarcity.
example_tasks: Explain dominance of arid and semi-arid climates: most region receives under 10 inches annual rainfall, deserts covering vast areas (Sahara, Arabian)
Identify critical water sources: Nile, Tigris-Euphrates, but most countries facing severe water stress
Describe oil/gas concentration: Persian Gulf region holding majority of world's reserves, foundation of regional economies

sub_topics.name: Conflicts and Instability
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding region's numerous conflicts.
example_tasks: Identify ongoing conflicts: Syrian civil war, Yemen war, Libya instability, Iraq sectarian violence, Israeli-Palestinian conflict
Explain sectarian tensions: Sunni-Shia divide particularly Iran vs. Saudi Arabia, but conflicts have multiple causes beyond religion
Analyze Arab Spring: 2011 uprisings toppled some dictators but mostly led to instability or repression, showing democratization challenges

sub_topics.name: Oil Dependence and Diversification
sub_topics.short_description: Examining economic structures based on petroleum.
example_tasks: Describe Gulf states' oil dependence: Saudi Arabia, UAE, Kuwait deriving 70-90% government revenues from oil
Explain Dutch disease effects: oil wealth appreciating currencies, undermining non-oil sectors, creating single-commodity dependence
Evaluate diversification efforts: UAE and Saudi Arabia investing in tourism, finance, renewable energy preparing for post-oil future

sub_topics.name: Sub-Saharan Africa
sub_topics.short_description: Examining world's poorest but rapidly growing region.

sub_topics.name: Physical Geography of Africa
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Africa's diverse environments.
example_tasks: Map climatic diversity: tropical rainforest (Congo Basin), savanna (Sahel, East Africa), desert (Sahara, Kalahari), Mediterranean (South Africa)
Explain Great Rift Valley: tectonic rift splitting Africa, creating lakes, mountains, geothermal activity
Identify major rivers: Nile (longest), Congo, Niger, Zambezi, with Victoria Falls and other major waterfalls

sub_topics.name: Development Challenges
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding obstacles to African development.
example_tasks: Identify factors: colonial legacy (extractive institutions, arbitrary borders), conflicts, corruption, weak governance, inadequate infrastructure
Explain geographic disadvantages: many landlocked countries, tropical diseases, dependence on primary commodity exports
Describe poverty persistence: 40% living on under $1.90/day despite recent growth, though progress varies greatly by country

sub_topics.name: Africa's Growth and Potential
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding recent economic progress and future prospects.
example_tasks: Analyze growth acceleration: many African economies growing 5-6% annually 2000s-2010s, driven by commodities, services, urbanization
Identify positive trends: democratic governance improving, conflicts declining, mobile phone revolution enabling development leapfrogging
Describe demographic dividend potential: young, growing population could drive growth if educated and employed, or instability if frustrated

sub_topics.name: African Subregions
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing different parts of Africa.
example_tasks: Compare regions: West Africa (populous, English/French, oil in Nigeria), East Africa (agricultural, safari tourism, tech hubs), Southern Africa (most developed, minerals)
Identify regional leaders: South Africa (largest economy but inequality), Nigeria (most populous, oil-dependent), Kenya (East African hub), Ethiopia (rapid growth)
Explain that Africa's 54 countries show enormous diversity in development, governance, culture, defying generalizations

name: Contemporary Global Issues in Geography
short_description: Synthesis of geographic knowledge to address current global challenges including pandemics, technology impacts, urbanization, food security, and emerging geographic concerns. Students integrate concepts to analyze complex issues.

sub_topics.name: Geography of Pandemics and Disease
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding spatial patterns and impacts of disease outbreaks.

sub_topics.name: Disease Diffusion Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how diseases spread spatially.
example_tasks: Analyze COVID-19 diffusion: hierarchical (major cities first), contagious (local spread), network-based (air travel routes)
Compare historical pandemics: Black Death spreading along trade routes, 1918 flu accelerated by troop movements
Explain factors affecting spread: population density, mobility, connectivity, public health measures

sub_topics.name: Geographic Health Disparities
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding unequal disease burdens and health outcomes.
example_tasks: Map global disease burden: communicable diseases dominant in poor countries, non-communicable in wealthy, with some countries facing double burden
Analyze pandemic impacts: COVID-19 disproportionately affecting minorities, urban poor, essential workers showing social and spatial inequalities
Explain healthcare access disparities: rural areas, developing countries lacking facilities, personnel, medical supplies

sub_topics.name: One Health and Zoonotic Diseases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding connections between human, animal, and environmental health.
example_tasks: Explain zoonotic disease emergence: 75% of emerging diseases jumping from animals to humans (Ebola, SARS, COVID-19)
Identify risk factors: deforestation bringing humans closer to wildlife, wildlife trade, industrial animal agriculture creating disease reservoirs
Describe One Health approach: integrating human, veterinary, environmental medicine to prevent disease emergence

sub_topics.name: Digital Technologies and Geography
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how technology reshapes spatial patterns and geographic analysis.

sub_topics.name: Big Data and Geospatial Analytics
sub_topics.short_description: Using massive datasets for geographic insights.
example_tasks: Explain how mobile phone data reveals movement patterns, social networks, economic activity at unprecedented scale and granularity
Describe satellite imagery analysis using machine learning to map poverty, detect deforestation, assess crop health globally
Analyze social media geographic data showing sentiment, language patterns, cultural diffusion, disaster response in real-time

sub_topics.name: Smart Cities and IoT
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding sensor networks and data-driven urban management.
example_tasks: Describe smart city technologies: traffic sensors optimizing flows, smart meters managing energy, environmental sensors monitoring air quality
Evaluate benefits and concerns: efficiency gains versus surveillance concerns, data privacy, digital divide, over-reliance on technology
Research examples: Singapore's comprehensive smart nation program, Barcelona's smart city initiatives

sub_topics.name: Location-Based Services and Apps
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how location awareness transforms services and behavior.
example_tasks: Analyze how apps like Uber, Airbnb, delivery services rely on GPS enabling new economic models and spatial patterns
Explain check-in culture and geotagging creating location data trails, enabling targeted advertising but raising privacy concerns
Describe how location data reveals activity patterns, social networks, even political views, with implications for surveillance

sub_topics.name: Urbanization and Megacities
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the urban century and challenges of massive cities.

sub_topics.name: Global Urban Transition
sub_topics.short_description: Examining humanity's shift to predominantly urban living.
example_tasks: Calculate that over 55% of humanity now lives in cities, projected to reach 68% by 2050, making this the urban century
Explain that urbanization is fastest in Africa and Asia, with cities in these regions absorbing 2.5 billion additional urban residents by 2050
Compare developed country stable urbanization (~80-85%) with developing countries rapidly urbanizing from 40-50%

sub_topics.name: Megacity Challenges
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding problems facing cities over 10 million people.
example_tasks: Identify challenges: congestion, pollution, informal settlements, inequality, infrastructure strain, climate vulnerability in cities like Mumbai, Lagos, Jakarta
Analyze governance difficulties: megacities often spanning multiple jurisdictions, requiring metropolitan-scale coordination
Compare megacities in developed (Tokyo, New York, relatively well-managed) versus developing countries (facing more severe challenges)

sub_topics.name: Urban Opportunities and Innovation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding cities as engines of economic growth and creativity.
example_tasks: Explain agglomeration benefits: cities concentrating labor, knowledge, capital enabling productivity, innovation, economic growth
Describe how cities are laboratories for sustainability: dense settlement enables efficient transit, district heating, shared resources
Identify urban social benefits: diversity, cultural amenities, anonymous freedom, though also anonymity and alienation

sub_topics.name: Global Food Security Crisis
sub_topics.short_description: Examining challenges feeding growing population sustainably.

sub_topics.name: Hunger and Malnutrition
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding persistent food insecurity despite adequate global production.
example_tasks: Calculate that ~800 million people experience chronic hunger despite world producing enough food for everyone, indicating distribution and access problems
Explain hidden hunger: 2 billion suffering micronutrient deficiencies even when calorie needs met, due to poor diet quality
Identify that hunger concentrated in conflict zones, failed states, and regions with chronic poverty

sub_topics.name: Agricultural Intensification Debates
sub_topics.short_description: Examining approaches to increasing food production.
example_tasks: Compare industrial agriculture (high inputs, mechanization, monocultures, high yields) with small-scale farming (lower inputs, diverse crops, labor-intensive)
Debate whether feeding 10 billion people requires further intensification or whether sustainable practices can provide sufficient food
Analyze precision agriculture using sensors, drones, AI to optimize inputs reducing environmental impact while maintaining yields

sub_topics.name: Transforming Food Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding need for sustainable, equitable food systems.
example_tasks: Explain food system problems: environmental degradation, greenhouse gas emissions (25% of total), biodiversity loss, unhealthy diets, food waste (1/3 lost)
Describe needed transformations: sustainable intensification, dietary shifts (less meat), reducing waste, supporting small farmers, reforming agricultural policies
Research alternative food systems: urban agriculture, local food movements, agroecology, though debated whether sufficient at scale

sub_topics.name: Oceans and Marine Geography
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ocean ecosystems, resources, and governance.

sub_topics.name: Ocean Resources and Blue Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Examining economic activities based on marine resources.
example_tasks: Identify ocean economic activities: fisheries, shipping, offshore energy, tourism, potentially deep-sea mining, contributing trillions to global economy
Explain blue economy concept: sustainable use of ocean resources balancing economic development with conservation
Describe competing demands: conservation versus exploitation, developed versus developing country interests, present versus future generations

sub_topics.name: Ocean Health and Threats
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding degradation of marine ecosystems.
example_tasks: Identify threats: overfishing (30% of stocks overexploited), pollution (plastics, chemicals), acidification (absorbing CO2), warming (coral bleaching, species shifts)
Explain that oceans provide critical services: oxygen production, carbon sequestration, climate regulation, food, threatened by human activities
Describe dead zones: ocean areas with too little oxygen to support life, caused by nutrient pollution from agriculture

sub_topics.name: Ocean Governance and Law of the Sea
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding international frameworks for ocean management.
example_tasks: Explain UNCLOS (UN Convention on Law of the Sea): establishing territorial waters (12 nm), EEZs (200 nm), international waters, deep seabed as common heritage
Identify governance challenges: tragedy of the commons in international waters, illegal fishing, enforcing regulations over vast areas
Describe marine protected areas: protecting ~8% of oceans, though scientists recommend 30-50% protection for effective conservation

sub_topics.name: Emerging Geographic Futures
sub_topics.short_description: Examining potential future geographic transformations.

sub_topics.name: Space: The Final Geographic Frontier
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding geographic dimensions of space activities.
example_tasks: Describe growing space economy: satellites (communication, GPS, Earth observation), space tourism beginning, asteroid mining potential
Explain geopolitics of space: national prestige, military applications, international cooperation (ISS) versus competition (Moon, Mars claims)
Identify that space resources and territory governance remains underdeveloped, with Outer Space Treaty (1967) prohibiting national appropriation but unclear on private exploitation

sub_topics.name: Climate Migration and Displacement
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding future population movements from climate change.
example_tasks: Project that 200+ million people may be displaced by 2050 due to sea level rise, droughts, extreme weather, though estimates uncertain
Identify vulnerable regions: low-lying islands (Maldives, Marshall Islands, Tuvalu), deltas (Bangladesh, Nile), drought-prone areas (Sahel, Central America)
Analyze that most climate migration will be internal (rural to urban, region to region) with some international movement, legal frameworks inadequate

sub_topics.name: Technological Disruption of Geography
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how emerging technologies may reshape spatial patterns.
example_tasks: Describe how automation and AI could reduce manufacturing's labor intensity, potentially enabling reshoring but providing fewer jobs
Explain remote work possibilities: potentially reducing urban concentration, enabling rural revival, though digital divide and social needs complicate
Identify autonomous vehicles potentially reshaping cities: reduced parking needs, sprawl enablement, or dense transit-oriented development depending on regulation
